<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>
<div>Na afloop van de cursus kan de student:

column2: • de sociaal-wetenschappelijke, interpretatieve en kritische onderzoeksbenaderingen binnen communicatie­onderzoek onderscheiden en relateren aan het type onderzoeksvragen en onderzoeksmethoden dat daarbij centraal staat
• voor een eigen onderzoek relevante wetenschappelijke bronnen te vinden, selecteren en beoordelen
• kan een onderzoeksvraag formuleren, deze theoretisch inbedden en verantwoorden op basis van een beperkte hoeveelheid literatuur
• een adequaat onderzoeksvoorstel schrijven.
• de verschillende onderdelen van een wetenschappelijk verslag identificeren en weet aan welke criteria deze onderdelen moeten voldoen

• verschillende voor communicatieonderzoek relevante (kwalitatieve en kwantitatieve) onderzoeks­methoden vergelijken en een beredeneerde keuze maken voor een methode en onderzoeksobjecten gegeven een bepaalde onderzoeksvraag

column1: De student is zich bewust van de ethische aspecten van wetenschappelijk onderzoek.

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

Deze cursus herhaalt relevante onderzoeksbenaderingen en onderzoeksmethoden die binnen communicatieonderzoek aan bod zijn gekomen in de basispakketten, en bereidt de studenten voor op het uitvoeren van een communicatieonderzoek in het verlengde van het gekozen verdiepingspakket.

De studenten ontwikkelen daarnaast het onderzoeksvoorstel voor het onderzoek dat ze in het kader van hun eindwerkstuk gaan uitvoeren. Daartoe hebben ze gedurende de cursus enkele malen contact met de beoogde begeleider van het eindwerkstuk waarbij (1) het zoeken en verwerken van relevante literatuur, (2) het afleiden van een onderzoeksvraag en (3) de keuze van een geschikte onderzoeksmethode aan de orde komen.
Ten slotte lezen en beoordelen studenten verslagen van eindwerkstukken waarbij de vraag centraal staat uit welke onderdelen deze verslagen bestaan en welke eisen aan deze verslagen worden gesteld.
Het CIW lab volg je in het verlengde van je verdiepingspakket:
LET OP: Wanneer je je inschrijft voor het CIW Lab kies je dan ook voor de groep die aansluit op het verdiepingspakket
1.         Digitale communicatie: Schrijf je in voor groep 2 óf groep 4  (thema Media en Cultuur)
2.         Media, communicatie en markt: Schrijf je in voor groep 2 óf groep 4 (thema Media en Cultuur)
3.         Communicatie, organisatie en interactie:Schrijf je in voor groep 1 óf groep 3 (thema Communicatie)
4.         Cultuur, communicatie en diversiteit: Schrijf je in voor groep 2 óf groep 4 (thema Media en Cultuur)

https://osiris-student.uu.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/177047,2017,Cultural and artistic didactics,Dutch,Graduate School of Teaching,,['drs. A.J. Westermann', 'drs. N.J. Nannes', 'M.P. Nagtzaam, MA']",,"Course goals

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>
Na afloop van de cursus heeft de student:
- inzicht in hoe (verschillend) het vak CKV wordt ingericht op verschillende scholen en welke keuzes daarbij doorslaggevend zijn;
- kennis van de domeinen van het examenprogramma CKV (Verkennen, Verbreden, Verdiepen en Verbinden) en doorloopt deze;

- een visiestuk geschreven waarin oa in wordt gegaan op de verschillende visies op kunst- en cultuureducatie; de invulling van CKV op de stageschool; het aanbod aan lesmateriaal en het belang van een ‘goede’ CKV-docent.</body>

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

<body>In deze keuzecursus staat de didactiek van het schoolvak Culturele en Kunstzinnige Vorming (CKV) centraal. Het doel is om kennis en inzichten te verwerven die je helpen verantwoorde en authentieke keuzes te maken in onderwijzen van het vak CKV.  Als CKV docent heb je namelijk een belangrijke taak: het is aan jou leerlingen te motiveren en enthousiasmeren en hen te begeleiden in het vormen van een nieuwsgierige attitude wat betreft het ervaren en waarderen van culturele en kunstzinnige uitingen. In deze cursus onderzoeken we wat het vak (in praktijk en theorie) inhoudt, waarom er een nieuw examenprogramma ingevoerd is, wat het van je vraagt om een goede CKV docent te zijn en welke rol ICT hierbij speelt.</body>

De CRUX-toets is een kennisretentietoets, die als doel heeft om de basiskennis van studenten te versterken door eerder opgedane, klinisch relevante basiskennis uit de Bachelor Geneeskunde te herhalen.
De CRUX-toets bestaat uit vier deeltoetsen, CRUX-1, CRUX-2, CRUX-3 en CRUX-4. In iedere deeltoets zal stof uit 3 of 4 blokken worden herhaald. De inhoud van de CRUX-toetsen heeft betrekking op:

De CRUX-toets is onderdeel van de Bachelor Geneeskunde. In combinatie met de Utrechtse Voortgangstoets (UVT) in de Master Geneeskunde draagt de CRUX-toets bij aan een van de onderwijskundige kenmerken van CRU+: eenmaal verworven kennis blijft behouden gedurende de hele opleiding.

Per CRUX-toets zal een overzicht worden geboden van de onderwerpen/doelstellingen die aan bod komen. Verder geldt dezelfde literatuur voor de CRUX-toetsen als voor de blokken waarop de CRUX-toets betrekking heeft.
CRUX-toetsen zullen digitaal worden afgenomen en uitsluitend bestaan uit gesloten vragen. Per CRUX-toets zullen vier gelegenheden per jaar worden aangeboden waarop de toets gemaakt kan worden.
Voor iedere CRUX-toets afzonderlijk moet aan de volgende voorwaarden zijn voldaan:
-          De blokken waarop de CRUX-toets betrekking heeft moeten zijn doorlopen
-          De tentamens van de betreffende blokken moeten zijn gehaald

Aangezien de CRUX-toetsen niet van elkaar afhankelijk zijn is het behalen van een eerdere CRUX-toets geen voorwaarde voor het maken van de volgende CRUX-toets. De eerste mogelijkheid voor het maken van CRUX-1 is in september van Bachelor jaar 2. </body>

column1: <meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

column2: <body>

column4: As members of the Netherlands Research School in Philosophy (OZSW) or the National Research School in Classical Studies (OIKOS), Research Master's students complete one seminar each year that is selected from a course list coordinated by the research schools. These are either (1) designated seminars offered by various Dutch universities (including Utrecht)  or (2) one of the research school's special offerings (e.g. the annual ""Autumn School"" for research master's students).(1) In the case of regularly offered courses, students register for the selected course at the host university (using that university's course code and title). The results for that course (including course title and grade) are then subsequently registered as Research School Seminar Year 1 (OFRM14001) or Research School Seminar Year 2 (OFRM14002).  (For more detailed instructions, contact the RMA Coordinator.) (2) In the case of special Research School offerings, credit and grades will be registered directly as Research School Seminar Year 1 (OFRM14001) or Research School Seminar Year 2 (OFRM14002), on the basis of a report provided to the RMA Coordinator by the coordinator of the research school event. Credits for the seminar varies, but the number of credits for the two Research School Seminars must add up to at least 10 ECTS.

Students who are abroad in their second year are advised to complete both courses during their first year. Information about available courses : http://www.ru.nl/oikos/research-master/ma-courses/ http://www.ozsw.nl/courses-seminars-for-research-master-students/ Useful instructions: http://www.ozsw.nl/exchange-between-dutch-universities/

column2: </body>

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

As members of the Netherlands Research School in Philosophy (OZSW) or the National Research School in Classical Studies (OIKOS), Research Master's students complete seminars selected from a course list coordinated by the research schools. These are either (1) designated seminars offered by various Dutch universities (including Utrecht)  or (2) one of the research school's special offerings (e.g. the annual OZSW Winter school for Research Master's students).(1) In the case of regularly offered courses, students register for the selected course at the host university (using that university's course code and title). The results for that course (including course title and grade) are then subsequently registered as Research School Seminar Year 1 (OFRM14001) or Research School Seminar Year 2 (OFRM14002).  (For more detailed instructions, see the RMA Philosophy handbook.)(2) In the case of special Research School offerings, credit and grades will be registered directly as Research School Seminar Year 1 (OFRM14001) or Research School Seminar Year 2 (OFRM14002), on the basis of a report provided to the RMA Coordinator by the coordinator of the research school event. Credits for the seminar varies, but the number of credits for the two Research School Seminars must add up to at least 10 ECTS.

Students who are abroad in their second year are excused from the second year requirement. Information about available courses :http://www.ru.nl/oikos/research-master/ma-courses/ http://www.ozsw.nl/courses-seminars-for-research-master-students/Useful instructions: http://www.ozsw.nl/exchange-between-dutch-universities/

https://osiris-student.uu.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/182436,2017,Calculus and Linear Algebra,English,University College Utrecht,,['dr. G.S.K.S. Heuts', 'dr. P.A. Zegeling', 'dr. V.N.E. Blasjö']",,"Course goals

column2: <head><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>
<body>

column4: After completing this course students are able to:

column5: apply basic techniques of single-variable calculus, such as differentiation, integration and Taylor expansions,
find solutions to simple ordinary differential equations,
apply basic techniques of linear algebra, including matrix diagonalization,
optimize functions of several variables, with and without constraint,
understand and extend these techniques beyond the level of recipes so they can be applied to new problems in their future field of study,
make basic use of the symbolic manipulation program Mathematica for the purpose of evaluating expressions and creating graphs.

column2: </body>
<head><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>
<body>

column4: This introductory course focuses on basic concepts of calculus starting with functions of a single variable. First you explore simple linear and nonlinear differential equations. Such equations are key in explaining the dynamic behavior of many different systems in a wide variety of fields. This serves as a motivation to learn about techniques, such as differentiation, integration, expansion in a small variable, and complex numbers.

column5: Next you learn to use powerful tools to study systems of many variables: linear vector spaces, linear operators (matrices) in such spaces, and key properties of matrices. You also extend techniques such as differentiation to functions of several variables and learn about their geometrical representation. The course concludes with various approaches to optimization of functions of several variables.

The techniques you learn in this course have proven to be highly effective in a wealth of areas as will be illustrated by examples in various fields. Some attention is paid to underlying mathematical foundations, but the focus is on understanding the methods and on learning to apply the techniques.

column4: In addition to the four class hours a week spend on lectures, student presentations and guided practical work, students are expected to work for ten hours a week on average on self-study reading and problem solving, doing take-home assignments to be handed in, preparing their student presentations and studying for the exams.

column2: </body>

https://osiris-student.uu.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/176745,2017,Capita Selecta European Law: EU Asylum Law,English,Faculty of Law, Economics and Governance",,[],,"Course goals

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>
•        Students will gain critical and comprehensive understanding of the functioning Common European Asylum System
•        Students will be able to reflect on key challenges in the EU international protection regime.
•        Students will develop reasoned alternatives to the existing legal framework.
•        Students engage in detailed analysis of a single issue of particular interest through independent research and writing.</body>

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

This course covers the core issues of European law that define the scope of international protection from a comparative and integrated perspective which focuses on the refugee definition and protection under the 1951 Refugee Convention and the ways the European Union (EU) has been developing a Common European Asylum System to offer protection to refugees and other ‘forced migrants’. The CEAS is currently under reform and several options, including relocation, resettlement, humanitarian visa, have been considered to strengthen the effectiveness of the system while ensuring high guarantees for the applicants.
All these options will be considered in order to reflect on possible corrections and measures than improve the sustainability of the CEAS.

The course, therefore, aims to provide students with a critical understanding of the content, workings and shortcomings of European migration law and policy, taking into consideration the challenging interactions between international law, EU law and domestic law. By actively engaging with the readings, lectures and class discussions students will develop skills of legal analysis, synthesis and argumentation so that by the end of the course, students will have an understanding of both the potential, and the limits, of the scope of international protection under EU law.
Students will be divided into groups. Each group will be “on call” for one of the weeks of the course. “On call” students have 2 particular duties:
a) identify and elaborate 2 short questions/comments from relevant Basic readings that will be submitted a few days before class and will be presented and discussed in class;
b) be prepared to take the lead in responding to questions about the cases under discussion from the week’s materials.

All students are required to write short position paper(s) proposing changes to the existing measures, based on the background knowledge on EU asylum law acquired throughout the weekly lectures. During the last week of the module, you will present and defend your proposals and discuss the proposals of your fellow students. Your evaluation will be a combination of your position paper and your input in the weekly calls.

In period 3 you will follow 3 modules to be chosen from  modules on topics of European law. Period 3 is divided into 3 sub-periods of three weeks each. For each of the sub-periods you need to choose one module from the modules offered in that sub-period. It is not possible to do more than one modules in the same sub-period. A fourth module, which is compulsory, regards the Research and Thesis Trajectory (RTT), and starts already in period 1. This module must be completed before starting the actual writing of the thesis in period 4. One week in period 3 is dedicated entirely to the RTT and no capita selecta teaching is scheduled during that week. For more information on this module, see the separate information document on Blackboard. Each of modules equals 2,5 ECTS.

The modules allow you to submerge yourself into a specific area of European Union law in a small-scale setting (max. 15 students). It is an intense form of education, aimed at deepening your knowledge in a specific field of EU law and at developing skills which will be important for your professional career. This means that none of the modules will be concluded by an exam. Instead, you will be tested in other ways. You might have to write a position paper, a case note, a weblog, a policy advice paper or you may be tested on the basis of a presentation or your input in a negotiating exercise.

If you fail one of the modules, you may not repair your grade within that module. Instead, a reparation module will be offered in period 4. The content and approach of that module will only be made public at the end of period 3. If you fail more than one module, you will have to take the Capita Selecta course the next year.

https://osiris-student.uu.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/176704,2017,Capita Selecta European Law: EU External Affairs and International Trade,English,Faculty of Law, Economics and Governance",,"['dr. C.M.J. Ryngaert', 'dr. U. Jaremba, MA LLM']",,"Course goals

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

column2: • Students will further develop the basic knowledge of the concepts of international law and EU law, which they have acquired in the General Course on Public International Law and EU law master courses
• They will familiarize themselves with basic international law on the characterisation and responsibility of international organisations
• Students will consider key questions surrounding the hierarchy of norms within the international and EU legal systems
• They will examine issues regarding the acquisition of binding international obligations by individual states and international organisations

• Students will consider more generally the evolution of international law and the EU, and critically engage with how practitioners, Member States, the CJEU and academics have constantly considered and re-considered the relationship between international law and the EU

• Students learn to distil and evaluate legal questions from existing normative debates and provide reasoned answers to them by employing persuasive analysis or arguments using analogical and deductive reasoning
• Students learn to critically approach and assess the legal questions posed
• Students develop their research, analytical, writing and oral skills.

column1: <meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

Over the past decades, the European Union’s continued integration has given it a unique character as an international actor. While the EU characterises itself as a sui generis, autonomous and supranational legal order, this approach does not necessarily align with that of international law.

This module aims to discuss some key questions surrounding the interface between international law and the legal order of the European Union. In doing so, it seeks to uncover some inconsistencies between the international and EU approaches to the working of international law on both the EU and its member states. Interesting issues in this regard include EU competence to conclude international agreements such as Comprehensive Economic and Trade Agreement with Canada and the Kyoto Protocol, participation of the EU in international organisations such as the World Trade Organization, international responsibility, data protection in EU-US relations, and the hierarchy of international norms in the legal order of both the Union and its member states. The focus of the course is on questions of international trade and trade-related public policy measures.
This module is aimed at students with an interest in both public international and European law, and invites them to reflect critically on the EU’s growing role as a global actor. </body>

column1: <meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

The students will be divided into small groups representing a Member State or an Institution. They will negotiate the withdrawal agreement mentioned in article 50 TEU following the Brexit referendum and the British Government’s intention to leave the European Union. For the purposes of this exercise, we assume that the United Kingdom has notified the European Council of its intention to leave the European Union. The participants will first write a position paper elaborating the position of the Member State or institution they represent (reflecting the interests of the Member State/institution concerned and based on legal argumentation). During the last week the actual negotiations exercise will take place.

An alternative way to take this module is for students who are participating in the oral rounds of the European Law moot court. They follow an intense training, focusing on their skills to present legal arguments and to improvise, by a team of Moot court trainers, followed by the actual oral rounds in a city in Europe or the US. They will be graded on the basis of their overall performance.

In period 3 you will follow 3 modules to be chosen from modules on topics of European law. Period 3 is divided into 3 sub-periods of three weeks each. For each of the sub-periods you need to choose one modulefrom the modules offered in that sub-period. It is not possible to do more than one modules in the same sub-period. A fourth module, which is compulsory, regards the Research and Thesis Trajectory (RTT), and starts already in period 1. This module must be completed before starting the actual writing of the thesis in period 4. One week in period 3 is dedicated entirely to the RTT and no capita selecta teaching is scheduled during that week. For more information on this module, see the separate information document on Blackboard. Each of modules equals 2,5 ECTS.

The modules allow you to submerge yourself into a specific area of European Union law in a small-scale setting (max. 15 students). It is an intense form of education, aimed at deepening your knowledge in a specific field of EU law and at developing skills which will be important for your professional career. This means that none of the modules will be concluded by an exam. Instead, you will be tested in other ways. You might have to write a position paper, a case note, a weblog, a policy advice paper or you may be tested on the basis of a presentation or your input in a negotiating exercise.

If you fail one of the modules, you may not repair your grade within that module. Instead, a reparation module will be offered in period 4. The content and approach of that module will only be made public at the end of period 3. If you fail more than one module, you will have to take the Capita Selecta course the next year.

https://osiris-student.uu.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/185426,2017,Capita Selecta European Law: Economic and Monetary Union,English,Faculty of Law, Economics and Governance",,['mr. dr. T. van den Brink'],,"Course goals

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>
<div>This module aims at achieving the following objectives:

column2: • Students will familiarize themselves with key issues of current EMU governance.
• Students will research one such a key issue of EMU economic governance and come to a well-argued thesis on the basis of thorough research of primary and secondary resources.
• In the context of an academic conference simulation, students will present their research findings and seek to convince their peers of the central thesis they posit.
• Students will evaluate the academic relevance of the work of one of their peers and make relevant suggestions on how to improve their paper.
• Students will analyze EU legislation, doctrine, but most notably national and EU policy documents.
• Students develop their research, analytical, writing and oral skills.

column1: <meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

The Economic and Monetary Union (EMU) is arguably one of the best-known and most important aspects of EU integration, but it has also become one of the most controversial ones. The economic crisis that erupted in 2008 revealed the flaws of the system. Since then, EMU law has undergone major changes and it has also been supplemented with a permanent bail out system for Member States, the Economic Stability Mechanism (ESM).

Economic coordination – unlike supranational monetary policy – is based on cooperation between EU institutions and national authorities. The European Semester is the yearly cycle of economic policy coordination that has been set up. In 2015, the European Commission decided to include more policy objectives. Objectives to pursue structural economic reforms and sound public finances have been supplemented with employment and social objectives and with democratic objectives.

The key objective of this module is to assess the legitimacy of the current system of EMU law and possible alternatives as well as future changes thereto. Students will focus on a particular element and/or perspective. This may be substantive (e.g. balancing social and economic interests; the effectiveness of EMU policies), institutional (e.g. democratic control, division of power between the EU and the Member States), comparative (assessing the impact of EMU policies across Member States) etc. Students are encouraged to assess not only legal frameworks, but to look in particular also at the actual functioning of the EMU (by e.g. including concrete decisions of the ECB, the Commission etc. The module, thus, combines legal and political science/ public administration methods.

In period 3 you will follow 3 modules to be chosen from modules on topics of European law. Period 3 is divided into 3 sub-periods of three weeks each. For each of the sub-periods you need to choose one module from the modules offered in that sub-period. It is not possible to do more than one modules in the same sub-period. A fourth module, which is compulsory, regards the Research and Thesis Trajectory (RTT), and starts already in period 1. This module must be completed before starting the actual writing of the thesis in period 4. One week in period 3 is dedicated entirely to the RTT and no capita selecta teaching is scheduled during that week. For more information on this module, see the separate information document on Blackboard. Each of modules equals 2,5 ECTS.

The modules allow you to submerge yourself into a specific area of European Union law in a small-scale setting (max. 15 students). It is an intense form of education, aimed at deepening your knowledge in a specific field of EU law and at developing skills which will be important for your professional career. This means that none of the modules will be concluded by an exam. Instead, you will be tested in other ways. You might have to write a position paper, a case note, a weblog, a policy advice paper or you may be tested on the basis of a presentation or your input in a negotiating exercise.

If you fail one of the modules, you may not repair your grade within that module. Instead, a reparation module will be offered in period 4. The content and approach of that module will only be made public at the end of period 3. If you fail more than one module, you will have to take the Capita Selecta course the next year.

•        in the thesis module, the student has learned how to write a solid and convincing research paper and will further familiarize him-/herself with legal-scientific methods.
•        in the other modules, the student has learned to quickly familiarize him-/herself with new legal topics and problems.

•        in the other modules, the student has learned and to analyze these new legal topics in a short period of time. In doing so, he/she will acquire, or further develop, different skills such as finding relevant sources of information, analyzing case-law and other legal and policy documents, connecting theory and practice, conducting negotiations, writing memoranda, presenting findings, orally defending arguments, and evaluating and giving feedback to other students’ work.

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

Have you heard about Europol, Frontex or the European Fisheries Control Agency? Did you know that there are 35 EU agencies and that agencies have become not only important decision-making but also supervisory entities at the EU level? For those who know little about and are simply interested in this relatively new but important development of EU law and governance, we are happy to offer our course! This course will advance the knowledge of the EU institutional law by exposing students to the issues of enforcement of EU law by EU agencies and their national counterparts. Also, it creates a good possibility to train professional skills, such as research, writing, critical evaluation and presentation. The course concludes by the creation of a joint blog presenting the results of all groups’ papers and their comparative analysis.
Background and key focus of the course:

Enforcing EU law has since recently become a task of an increasing number of EU institutions and agencies[4. As a result of the EU recent financial reform, the European Central Bank, for instance, directly supervises significant credit institutions, “representing almost 85% of total banking assets in the euro area.”[1] Together with the possibility to withdraw a bank authorization, its enforcement arsenal includes administrative sanctions. In addition, the financial reform has led to the creation of a number of independent financial supervisors, including the European Securities and Markets Authority (ESMA). ESMA’s enforcement authority includes the powers to examine and take copies of any relevant records and materials, ask for oral explanations, summon and hear persons, require telephone and data traffic records, and interview persons. Such powers are not available even to the European Parliament in its investigatory capacity. Furthermore, Frontex, a European Agency for the Management of Operational Cooperation at the External Borders of the Member States of the European Union, has recently turned into an agency with own operational enforcement capacity. Following its modified founding regulation (amended by Regulation 1168/2011), the agency has finalized a tender to buy aerial surveillance to be used in joint operations[2] (instead of relying on the equipment of the EU Member States). The border guards are not anymore only those of Member States. The so-called Seconded Guest Officers (SGO) are employed by Frontex for up to six months per officer. The officers wear their own national uniform, but wear a blue Frontex and EU armband when deployed. The list of examples could continue but the point is clear: the EU has been acquiring direct enforcement power (i.e., monitoring, investigation and punishment in relation to individuals and companies, not only in relation to the EU Member States).

At the same time, while EU institutions and agencies have acquired direct supervisory powers, the exercise of those powers can be dependent on or shared with national level authorities (supervising institutions and courts). For instance, when ESMA needs to examine and to take copies of any relevant records and materials of a credit rating agency hosted in London, it has to obtain first an authorization of an English judge.[3] What if an English judge refuses to give such an authorization? Will ESMA render account for not doing her job or should the judge be accountable? By whom/at what level would they render accountability?

Since the trend of empowering EU entities with direct enforcement powers is quite recent, little is known about how shared enforcement is organized between EU and national authorities. What does an EU entity (institution, agency) and a national supervising authority do exactly when they enforce EU law? Are their tasks divided/subordinated to each other or do they share enforcement tasks? How and at what level do they render (political, judicial) accountability for the enforcement tasks? We invite students to explore these questions in the cases of their choice (an EU agency – one or more national counterparts of any EU Member State).

Having followed this course, students will advance their knowledge of the EU institutional law in three respects. Firstly, EU law is usually studied from a regulatory perspective (e.g., how regulations and directives are being made, in according with what procedures, on what topics, etc.). This is because the Treaties have been giving predominately regulatory tasks to the EU institutions. In this course, the focus is on the next stage of the EU policy cycle, namely enforcement: how do EU and national authorities make sure that EU law is complied with by individuals and private parties? How can the respective authorities investigate suspicious cases and punish for non-compliance? Secondly, EU law courses focus usually on the main EU institutions. EU agencies, which are hardly regulated by the Treaties, are normally discussed very briefly, if at all. In this course, students will be introduced to the EU agency phenomenon, which has become an important part of EU governance. The number of EU agencies has been proliferating in the recent years considerably (from approximately 10 to 35 in the last 15 years!). And their powers have become to include not only information-gathering but also decision-making and supervision. It is therefore important to get familiar with these new important actors at the EU policy making and implementing level. Thirdly, during this course a number of important skills for EU legal professionals will be trained: research, writing, critical evaluation and presentation skills. All in all, this course is a valuable supplement to the courses of the EU law master programme and possibly other interested students. It aims to complete the knowledge on the EU institutional law by focusing on the novel questions and challenges with which EU law and governance have been dealing within and outside the Treaties’ borders.

Students are offered to participate in interactive lectures, which will be based on academic and officials materials announced before the lecture. Lectures will be followed by debates in the form of seminars where more specific problems and challenges to shared enforcement will be discussed. Furthermore, students will be invited to form groups for their writing assignments and presentations. Groups of students will be given the chance to improve their paper after having submitted a first draft. The teaching staff and other groups will give their comments on written drafts and presentations. Depending on the number of participants, this course will be concluded by creating one/more blogs on the main topic, including the results of all group investigations.
[1] This information is taken from the official webpage of the ECB. Find at:  http://www.ecb.europa.eu/ssm/html/index.en.html.

[2] Annual Information on the Commitments of the Member States to the European Border Guard Teams and the Technical Equipment Pool, Report 2014. Available at: http://www.statewatch.org/news/2014/mar/eu-frontex-rep-ep-msd.pdf  (last check June 2015), pp. 7, 12.
[3] See the recent case at http://www.bailii.org/ew/cases/EWHC/Ch/2015/1085.html
[4] M. Scholten & M. Luchtman (eds) Law Enforcement by EU Authorities. Political and judicial accountability in shared enforcement, Edward Elgar, 2017

In period 3 you will follow 3 modules to be chosen from modules on topics of European law. Period 3 is divided into 3 sub-periods of three weeks each. For each of the sub-periods you need to choose one module from modules offered in that sub-period. It is not possible to do more than one modules in the same sub-period. A fourth module, which is compulsory, regards the Research and Thesis Trajectory (RTT), and starts already in period 1. This module must be completed before starting the actual writing of the thesis in period 4. One week in period 3 is dedicated entirely to the RTT and no capita selecta teaching is scheduled during that week. For more information on this module, see the separate information document on Blackboard. Each of modules equals 2,5 ECTS.

The modules allow you to submerge yourself into a specific area of European Union law in a small-scale setting (max. 15 students). It is an intense form of education, aimed at deepening your knowledge in a specific field of EU law and at developing skills which will be important for your professional career. This means that none of the modules will be concluded by an exam. Instead, you will be tested in other ways. You might have to write a position paper, a case note, a weblog, a policy advice paper or you may be tested on the basis of a presentation or your input in a negotiating exercise.

If you fail one of the modules, you may not repair your grade within that module. Instead, a reparation module will be offered in period 4. The content and approach of that module will only be made public at the end of period 3. If you fail more than one module, you will have to take the Capita Selecta course the next year.

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>
At the end of the course students:
- Will have insight in the historical development of EU gender and non-discrimination law
- Will have insight in key concepts in EU non-discrimination law as codified in diverse EU directives and interpreted by the Court of Justice of the EU
- Will be able to critically assess these developments and conceptualisation of the principle of equality from diverse perspectives
- will have insight in a few national law systems of EU member states in relation to gender equality and non-discrimination law.
At the end of the course students:

column2: <tbody>

column4: - Will be able to assimilate knowledge on a complicated field of law in a short period of time
- Will be able to assess critically the relevant existing EU law and express their findings in plenary discussions
- Will learn how to find reliable information on relevant national law
- Will be able to give short oral presentations in English
- Will be able to develop their own opinion on diverse issues at stake and present their opinions in class.
- Will develop their written skills in English by writing a paper
- Will be able to give and receive feedback on their (draft) paper

column2: </tbody>

column1: <meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

EU equality and non-discrimination law has developed since 1957 and consists now of an extensive body of law which has a great impact on national law of the Member States. EU equality law offers diverse tools to combat discrimination on the ground of sex/gender, race and ethnicity, religion and belief, sexual orientation, disability and age. The case law of the Court of Justice of the EU on sex/gender equality is particularly interesting, as some key concepts and approaches that have been developed in this area apply also to other fields of law and legal doctrine thereon is extensive. The focus during this course is therefore on sex/gender equality law.

The Court of Justice has developed key concepts such as the concept of indirect discrimination, which allows to bring more hidden forms of discrimination within the scope of EU law. It had also to consider in which cases direct sex discrimination is at stake and prohibited. Is an employer for example required to pay a Christmas bonus to women who have been absent during a few months due to pregnancy and maternity leave? Is an employer allowed to refuse the renewal of a fixed-term contract in case of pregnancy? Is positive action for women at universities allowed, even if this means that male candidates which fulfil the requirements cannot apply for certain functions? In how far is pay transparency required in order to combat gender pay gaps?
Improving a better gender balance in company boards is now one of the priorities of the European Commission. In addition, improved work life balance rights are on the agenda of the EU.

These are examples of issues that will be addressed in this learning by doing course. Discussions between lecturers and students will be at the core of the seminars. The course aims at enhancing students’ academic competences by encouraging critical assessments of existing law from different perspectives. The course will start in the first week with the study and assessment of the analytical and conceptual framework of EU gender equality law and its historical development. Attention will be paid to the notions of formal, substantive and transformative gender equality and how these may determine our assessment and appreciation of existing equality laws. The impact of EU gender equality law at the national level will be central during the second week of the course. Students will give oral presentations, preside and participate in debates in the class, defend statements and develop their own opinions, based on the analysis of case law of different national jurisdictions. In the third week, students will write a paper, and give and receive feedback on their paper. The evaluation will be based on the quality of the feedback, the oral presentation and the paper.

column1: <meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

Equality between men and women is one of the core values of the European Union. However, across the EU women are underrepresented in decision-making positions in politics and business. In November 2012, the Commission published a proposal for a Directive on improving the gender balance among non-executive directors of companies listed on stock exchanges (COM(2012) 614 final). The purpose of this proposal is to “substantially increase the number of women on corporate boards throughout the EU by setting a minimum objective of a 40% presence of the under-represented sex among the non-executive directors of companies listed on stock exchanges and by requiring companies with a lower share of the underrepresented sex among the non-executive directors to introduce pre-established, clear, neutrally formulated and unambiguous criteria in selection procedures for those positions in order to attain that objective” (p. 5 of the Explanatory Memorandum). Thus, the aim of this new legislation is to accelerate progress towards a better gender balance on the corporate boards of European companies. At the same time, numerous EU Member States have initiated national legislation or other measures in the field. National approaches vary from legislative to self- and co-regulatory ones. In this course module we will look at these measures to improve the gender balance in company boards. After an introduction of the European regulatory framework, we will study a few of the national approaches and compare these with the EU approach on this issue. Each student will be asked to study this theme from a different perspective in a paper. We shall then have joint sessions in which a debate can take place. The grade shall be given on the basis of the paper.
After the completion of this Caput, a student will be able to:

column2: • analyse a societal problem and define the relevant issues
• analyse and compare different approaches to regulate (and enforce) the relevant problem
• design a governmental advice.

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

column2: • The student is able to identify the goals, principles and rules of EU public procurement law and is aware of its legal, economic and policy background.

• The student is able to individually evaluate and critically asses cases based on self-constructed arguments in which the procedural role of EU public procurement law collides with its instrumental role.

column1: <meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

Every year, over 250.000 public authorities in the EU spend around 14-19% of their Member States’ GDP on the procurement of services, works and supplies. This amounts to a staggering 120 billion in the Netherlands alone. It is often in society’s best interest to put these expenditures up for tender. This allows public authorities to competitively purchase, for instance, healthcare services, highways or governmental office supplies for the lowest price and highest quality. Traditionally speaking, EU public procurement law ensures that the principles of equality (non-discrimination), transparency and proportionality are procedurally safeguarded in tendering procedures.

In its Europe 2020 strategy, the EU has, however, envisioned an additional instrumental role for public procurement. Public procurement must also contribute to policy goals, such as sustainability, innovation and social inclusion. This often means that public authorities require from tenderers to offer products that are produced without harming the environment or to use a workforce of previously long-term unemployed for the construction of an infrastructural project. Despite the enormous potential of this additional role, it can cause friction with the legal principles and (original) goals of EU public procurement law in practice.  In light of the social market economy, this caput analyses this new instrumental role of public procurement by evaluating which tensions exist and how they can be best dealt with based on the current legal framework of EU public procurement law.

column1: <meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

With regulated sectors we mean especially energy, telecom and transport. These sectors have been liberalized but are in fact subject to a variety regulatory regimes at the EU level which have as their main purpose to make markets work. Apart from those regimes and also the application of general competition rules (cartels, abuses of dominance) the companies in these sectors are subject to the enforcement of state aid rules enforced by the Commission. This enforcement is an interesting subject of study in particular in these sectors that often depend on public funding to some extent.
Achieve insight in the way state aid rules are enforced in the regulated sectors. Present a paper in this area in an understandable way.

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

column2: • the student has in-depth knowledge and understanding of a number of subareas of economic public law;

• the student has knowledge and an understanding of the interaction between European and international developments and economic public law and can take into consideration the international and societal context of economic public law in analysing this legal area;

• the student can independently acquire in-depth knowledge and understanding of an economic public law problem or issue in a short period of time, among other things with a view to his/her professional performance in the employment market;

• the student can independently acquire existing academic knowledge in a sound ethical and methodological manner, can value them, to critically reflect on them, and to systematically process and organise them.

• the student can communicate in English knowledge, ideas, solutions and conclusions, as well as the arguments, motives and considerations underlying them, to a public of specialists and non-specialists in an understandable, structured, correct and convincing manner;

• the student can make a link between theory and practice, particularly by analysing and putting forward solutions for legal issues that are topical in practice based on the theoretical knowledge and understanding he/she has acquired.

column1: <meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

When even the New York Times askes ‘Is it Time to Break Up Google’ and that sentiment is shared with European Parliament it is time to ask serious competition law questions: can European competition law be used to break up powerful companies? The easy answer, of course, is ‘no, it (currently) cannot’. The more difficult answer requires first a better understanding of the problem: why is the bigness of Google (and other Technological Giants) perceived as dangerous? What could the response from European competition law be?

This course will focus on the interplay between the big technological conglomerates and European competition law. Thus, the focus naturally lies on article 102 TFEU, which prohibits abuse of a dominant position (but not dominance itself). We will analyse whether applying existing legal tests – exclusive behaviour, exploitative behaviour – can adequately address the behaviour of these companies or whether ‘new’ standards are necessary. This might include a short foray into merger control, but this will not be the primary focus. Cases, such as the Google Shopping case, but also ‘older’ cases against technological giants as Microsoft, will be included in the analysis, but the analysis will move beyond the mere application of existing doctrines. Which stance should competition law take? And where current competition law falls short – in light of the problem analysis – would there be other ways of regulating the ‘bigness’ of technological companies?

- Students are able to understand and evaluate where the application of the abuse of dominance provision might fall short of solving the problems identified in relation to big technological companies, such as Google, Facebook and Apple.
- Students are able to formulate a precise analysis and evaluation of how these problems might be addressed.

• the student can make a link between theory and practice, particularly by analysing and putting forward solutions for legal issues that are topical in practice based on the theoretical knowledge and understanding he/she has acquired.

column1: <meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

A move towards a sustainable society and economy is high on the agenda of member states, the EU and global organizations. In this move towards more sustainable production methods, cooperation between companies is sometimes required. However, when companies enter into sustainability agreements, they run the risk of infringing European competition law. Applying the exception criteria proves difficult, as some high profile cases from the Netherlands – the Energy agreement, the Chicken of Tomorrow case – prove.

In this caput we will zoom in on this issue. We will try to tease apart why – and where in the legal scheme of the Treaty’s competition provisions - the relationship between sustainability initiatives and competition law is at odds. We will also try to formulate possible solutions.

Thus we will be focusing on an in-depth analysis of some of the sustainability initiatives, on the legal and regulatory response of the competition authorities, and of the legal provisions and concepts that play a role: article 101 (1) and (3), the Wouters-doctrine, the useful-effect doctrine and other concepts relevant to the tension at issue.
- Students are able to identify when and why tension occurs between sustainability initiatives and European competition law.
- Students can use and evaluate existing concepts and can analyse how these existing concepts might need to be adapted to provide a different outcome.

- Students can formulate a well-grounded argumentation relating to the whether such accommodation is necessary, both in light of the principles of sustainability, of competition law and regulation and rule of law requirements.

<body>Are search engine operators liable for referring to copyright infringing materials? And should internet access providers block P2P file sharing websites? In this module we focus on who’s responsibility for copyright infringements and other unlawful activities on the web. Current EU developments, such as the proposal for a new copyright directive and the CJEU’s case law regarding hyperlinking, are central to this module.</body>

This caput deals with corporate governance (the way corporations are directed and controlled). Bad corporate governance was one of the causes of the Financial crisis of 2007-2008. In this caput is explained how failures in the corporate governance can occur and the students are challenged to find out how these failures can be prevented. Real life cases (such as Enron and Uber) will be used to illustrate how bad corporate governance can lead to value destruction in corporations.
- theories of corporate governance (e.g. the agency theory, the stakeholder theory and the stewardship theory)

column1: <meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

Big data technology has many useful applications, but it clashes with the principles of data protection law. In this course you will get an overview of the data protection principles and will learn to assess to what extent big data practices are compatible with privacy principles. We do so by evaluating Facebook's privacy policy.
Capita Selecta Privaatrecht I (10 EC) en Capita Selecta Privaatrecht II (5 EC) (verder: CSP I en CSP II) zijn zogenaamd ""carrouselvakken"", waarbinnen u in totaal zes modules volgt.

We bieden op deze wijze een jaarlijks wisselend palet aan van actuele en spannende privaatrechtelijke onderwerpen in de vorm van kortlopende modules van drie weken. Zo'n module is een korte, hevige ‘onderdompeling’ in een juridisch probleem of kwestie van beperkte omvang. Elke module vergt veel zelfstudie, en is flexibel ingevuld (zowel qua onderwerp; groepsgrootte; toetsvorm; en taal). CSP heeft als belangrijk voordeel dat het u in staat stelt om binnen het vak aansluiting te zoeken bij uw eigen persoonlijke voorkeuren. Het inhoudelijke aanbod zal per jaar wisselen. Inhoudelijk kan dus alles dat met privaatrecht van doen heeft aan de orde komen.

Omdat we in een eenjarige masteropleiding niet alle privaatrechtelijke thema's en onderwerpen kunnen onderwijzen, kiezen we ervoor om de student grotendeels zelf, maar goed begeleid, de diepte in te laten gaan op een beperkt terrein. Binnen de genoemde modules kweekt u niet alleen op dat specifieke terrein veel kennis, maar ook de vaardigheid om u in een bepaald thema snel in te werken, net zoals u dat later als rechter of advocaat moet kunnen. Voor verdieping is begrip van de basis nodig; die zult u echter - indien nodig - zelf moeten bijspijkeren. Een probleem is dat niet, want het gebeurt binnen de context van een specifieke rechtsvraag.

Er is echter één module die een andere opzet heeft en die door iedereen moet worden gevolgd. Dat is de onderzoeksmodule. Tijdens deze module wordt de concept-onderzoeksopzet van de scriptie geschreven. Na de oriënterende fase van het OST-traject gaat u zelfstandig, doch onder begeleiding van een ervaren onderzoeker, aan de slag met uw scriptieonderwerp. U ontwerpt een probleemstelling, onderzoeksvraag, een methoden-sectie en een tekst over de wetenschappelijke en maatschappelijke relevantie van uw onderzoeksvraag.

Voor deze onderzoeksmodule ontvangt u geen cijfer, maar een voldoende of een onvoldoende.  Als u een voldoende haalt, krijgt u een scriptiebegeleider toegewezen. Deze scriptiebegeleider beoordeelt uw onderzoeksopzet opnieuw en geeft suggesties voor de definitieve onderzoeksopzet, aan de hand waarvan u uw scriptie gaat schrijven.
N.B. Als u een onvoldoende haalt voor de onderzoeksmodule, kunt u niet starten met uw scriptie. De vertraging die u hierdoor oploopt, heeft consequenties voor uw studieplanning.
Over de mogelijkheid om de onderzoeksmodule in een later blok te herkansen of in te halen, wordt u nog geïnformeerd.

Aan de vereisten van CSP I (10 EC) is voldaan zodra uit Osiris blijkt dat u drie modules met succes hebt behaald en ook aan de vereisten van de onderzoeksmodule is voldaan. Aan de vereisten van CSP II (5 EC) is voldaan, zodra uit Osiris blijkt dat ook voor de twee overige modules een voldoende is behaald.
Periode 3 is onderverdeeld in drie blokken van drie weken, hetgeen tot gevolg heeft dat u ieder blok twee modules volgt.

Binnen een module is geen reparatie mogelijk. Voor maximaal twee modules mag een onvoldoende worden behaald of door overmacht een ND worden verkregen.  Beroept u zich op overmacht, dan geldt deze overmacht ook voor de andere in hetzelfde blok gevolgde module.  De modules in de andere blokken moeten derhalve met succes worden afgerond. Als u een module moet repareren, kunt u voor een herkansingsmodule maximaal een 6 behalen.

Mocht u in periode 4 gebruik (moeten) maken van de reparatie of inhaalmogelijkheid, dan heeft dat invloed op uw scriptieplanning. Eventuele vertraging die u oploopt bij het schrijven van uw scriptie is uw eigen verantwoordelijkheid. De scriptiedeadline blijft onverkort gelden.

column1: <meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

Big technology companies such as Google and Facebook collect great amounts of data. These companies use these data to improve their services, for instance to produce personalized search results. But these data are also used to create profiles of users and to advertise more effectively. Most of these data are ‘personal data’ to which data protection and privacy law applies. However, competition authorities have also shown an interest in regulating these companies, for these data have become critical to building successful internet platforms. In this module we explore how privacy and competition law applies to the collection and use of these data, how these regimes may complement each other, but also where there is tension between the two.
It builds on the Data Protection I module.

column1: <meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

This caput provides introduction to the FinTech ecosystem and aims at understanding how financial technology is impacting traditional finance. Fintech is a term that is used a lot but not necessarily understood by everyone because it encompasses a breadth of players, products and issues as well as straddling the financial and several other sectors including telecommunications, retail, data analytics and device manufacturing. What unites these sectors is the “tech” in Fintech. Technology has always been a driver of growth and innovation in business but none more so than in the financial services sector. Understanding a combination of economics, finance, technology, government policy, regulation, strategy and importantly social and customer trends helps us to understand how innovation is accelerating change.
- demonstrate a broad understanding of how financial services have evolved and how they currently operate.
- explain how technology and regulation is impacting on financial services and the drivers behind this.
- be familiar with key financial, economic and technological terms and concepts and be able to communicate effectively about them.
- analyse and recognise the significance of trends and role of stakeholders in the Fintech environment and their impact on the future of Financial Services.

column1: <meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>
In this course we take a historical approach and try to come to a ‘legal-historical’ overview of the EU competition rules.

A history of cartel enforcement. In the first session we reflect on the development of the cartel enforcement activities from the European Commission form the early years in the 1960s and 70s to today. What major changes and differences can we discover and how can these be explained and contextualised?

A history of ideas. In the second session we reflect on the importance and influence of ideas in EU competition law. We first turn to the idea of ordoliberalism. What was the influence of this school on the shape of EU competition law. How has that changed today with the introduction of the ‘more economic approach’?

A history of case law. In the third session we reflect on the historical evolution of the case law of the European Court of Justice. Reflecting on the seminal case law we will try to come to an evolutionary perspective with respect to the courts approach to some of the major themes in EU competition law such as the object/effect distinction, the effects based approach in article 102 TFEU and the standard of proof for the European Commission.
- Understand the historical evolution of cartel enforcement in the European Union and be able to contextualise these developments;
- Have gained knowledge with respect to the relevance and influence of ideas for the structure and application of EU competition law;
- Have a deeper understanding of developments of the seminal case law and be able to discuss them from an evolutionary perspective.

This caput is part of the three capita in law and finance, which disentangle the rationales and main elements of financial regulation into three components: the “why”, the “how” and the “who”. This caput deals with the first aspect, the “why”. It uses the financial crisis of 2007-2008 as a starting point to explore the challenges of regulating global financial markets. The caput is internationally oriented and focuses on the market failures that came about in the financial sector and on the responses devised by the governments.

column2: • systemic risk and measures to curb it
• market integrity
• principal/agent problem
• goals of financial regulation and supervision

This caput is part of the three capita in law and finance, which disentangle the rationales and main elements of financial regulation into three components: the “why”, the “how” and the “who”. This caput deals with the second aspect, the “how”. It draws on the rules set by the global regulatory committees (Financial Stability Board, Basel Committee, ...), and on the European post-crisis regulation, with a few digressions and comparisons with the American regulatory debate.

• law-making procedure
• risk-models
• disclosure

This caput is part of the three capita in law and finance, which disentangle the rationales and main elements of financial regulation into three components: the “why”, the “how” and the “who”. This caput deals with the third aspect, the “Who”. It aims at getting to know the institutional design of banking regulation and supervision, with a specific focus on the EU Banking Union and Single Supervisory Mechanism.

column2: • EU institutions and ECB
• National Supervisors and Regulators
• The role of International Standard setters (Financial Stability Board, Basel Committee, ...)

column1: <meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

Students who performed very well in Competition I (minimum grade 8) may apply to the Utrecht Law&Economics moot court team (information regarding the procedure will be placed on Blackboard). Selected students (max 4) will be competing in the Kings College - Herbert Smith Freehills Competition Law Moot 2018.

The moot court is organised together with top tier Amsterdam based law firm Stibbe. The competition consists of a written and oral phase. The teams will submit a written memoranda which will be marked by competition law academics and practitioners.

As part of the moot court students will receive instructions on successfully drafting written pleadings. Participation in the moot court is free of costs and is funded by Stibbe. Students will be presenting their work at Stibbe and receive feedback and guidance from associates specialised in competition law.
In Moot Court I the focus will be on the written phase of the Moot Court - drafting of memoranda, layered argumentation, legal research in small teams.
- the student is able to identify the legal issues that are central to a factually and legally complex case
- the student is able to carry out in-depth legal research on an actual competition law case
- the student is able to prepare a written legal brief (memorial)
- the student is able to construct a layered argumentation using several techniques (legal reasoning)
- the student is able to conduct research in a small team (teamwork)</body>

This caput will focus on the latest developments in the regulatory framework on the EU policy objectives regarding "" the digital agenda"", aimed at the Digital Single Market, improving connectivity and access, advancing digital industry and building an European Data Economy and its regulatory framework. The main objective is to better understand the developments in the  relevant legal instruments.
​​Students will obtain a better understanding of the interplay between policy objectives, choices in instruments of regulation, and the protection of fundamental rights.

column1: <meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

How is the internet regulated? What issues do regulators face when they try to regulate activities on the internet? And, who is liable for the materials that is posted on platforms such as Facebook and YouTube? In this module, we dive into several subfields of EU law that regulate online activities. We will, for instance, consider the so-called 'right to be forgotten' and its implementation by search engines and data protection authorities. We will discuss the rules that the new Audiovisual Media Services Directive will introduce, which will apply to internet platforms as well. But we will also consider private enforcement, most notably by looking at the liability rules introduced in the E-Commerce Directive and the incentive they create for internet companies to keep the internet ‘clean’.

column2: • Students will have a basic understanding of privacy law, media law, and liability law, especially in relation to how these fields regulate online activities.
• Students will be able to identify the regulatory issues at stake when states try to regulate the internet.

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

column2: • the student has in-depth knowledge and understanding of a number of subareas of economic public law;

column1: <meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

Every year, over 250.000 public authorities in the EU spend around 14-19% of their Member States’ GDP on the procurement of services, works and supplies. This amounts to a staggering 120 billion in the Netherlands alone. It is often in society’s best interest to put these expenditures up for tender. This allows public authorities to competitively purchase, for instance, healthcare services, highways or governmental office supplies for the lowest price and highest quality. Traditionally speaking, EU public procurement law ensures that the principles of equality (non-discrimination), transparency and proportionality are procedurally safeguarded in tendering procedures.

In its Europe 2020 strategy, the EU has, however, envisioned an additional instrumental role for public procurement. Public procurement must also contribute to policy goals, such as sustainability, innovation and social inclusion. This often means that public authorities require from tenderers to offer products that are produced without harming the environment or to use a workforce of previously long-term unemployed for the construction of an infrastructural project. Despite the enormous potential of this additional role, it can cause friction with the legal principles and (original) goals of EU public procurement law in practice.  In light of the social market economy, this caput analyses this new instrumental role of public procurement by evaluating which tensions exist and how they can be best dealt with based on the current legal framework of EU public procurement law.

column2: • The student is able to identify the goals, principles and rules of EU public procurement law and is aware of its legal, economic and policy background.

• The student is able to individually evaluate and critically asses cases based on self-constructed arguments in which the procedural role of EU public procurement law collides with its instrumental role.
