In doing so, he/she will acquire, or further develop, different skills such as finding relevant sources of information, analyzing case-law and other legal and policy documents, connecting theory and practice, conducting negotiations, writing memoranda, presenting findings, orally defending arguments, and evaluating and giving feedback to other students’ work.

column1: <meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

With regulated sectors we mean especially energy, telecom and transport. These sectors have been liberalized but are in fact subject to a variety regulatory regimes at the EU level which have as their main purpose to make markets work. Apart from those regimes and also the application of general competition rules (cartels, abuses of dominance) the companies in these sectors are subject to the enforcement of state aid rules enforced by the Commission. This enforcement is an interesting subject of study in particular in these sectors that often depend on public funding to some extent.
Achieve insight in the way state aid rules are enforced in the regulated sectors. Present a paper in this area in an understandable way.</body>

https://osiris-student.uu.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/176851,2017,Capita Selecta Public International Law: Cultural Defence in International Criminal Law,English,Faculty of Law, Economics and Governance",,['prof. dr. T. Zwart'],,"Course goals

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

column2: • Students will learn to critically question some of the assumptions underlying international criminal law
• Students will gain knowledge of the legal defences recognised in international criminal law
• Students will learn how to rely on disciplines other than law, in particular anthropology, to strengthen their legal case
• Students will learn how to think outside their own cultural boxes
• Students will learn how to represent clients with worldviews other than their own
• Students will learn to develop trial strategies
• Students will learn to approach law from a multidisciplinary perspective.

column1: <meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

Defendants in international criminal law cases sometimes invoke their culture to claim that their acts are not punishable. Thus, a defendant prosecuted before the Special Court for Sierra Leone claimed that recruiting child soldiers was encouraged in his culture, which favours toughening up children to prepare them for adult life. Another defendant, who had 'bulletproofed' soldiers with the help of a potion, claimed that the only soldiers who would die regardless where those who did not live up to the requirements of international humanitarian law, on which the effectiveness of the potion depended.

Some sceptics reject these arguments as 'lame cultural excuses' or undesirable manifestations of cultural relativism. Others take the view that such claims constitute legitimate cultural defences which amount to errors of fact or errors of law, or even go to mens rea. Ignoring them may rob defendants of a fair trail. Furthermore, rejecting such defences may seriously erode the legitimacy of international criminal law, as is already visible in the opposition of African states to the behaviour of the International Criminal Court (ICC).

This module is designed to introduce the students to some of the dilemmas defence counsel, prosecutors and judges face. How can the reliability and veracity of such claims be established? What should be the legal consequences if the claim appears to be genuine? Most of the defendants are still from the Global South, while most of the lawyers representing them are still from the Global North. Some Northern lawyers avoid raising defences in this area, because they are unfamiliar with the cultural background of their clients and the resulting defence opportunities. However, ignoring these issues may deprive their clients of the opportunity of acquittal or a lighter sentence. Therefore, it is important to gain some insight in these matters, which may make the difference between conviction and acquittal.

After an introduction to the field, some challenging cases will be discussed. The students will be invited to argue opposite sides of these cases. The legal analysis will be supported with the help of insights from anthropology. The aim of the course is to show why cultural defences should be part of the toolbox of defence counsel.

The course is taught by Prof. Tom Zwart, who has been registered as an expert in this field, called forensic ethnology, by the ICC. Prof. Zwart currently serves as a member of a defence team representing a client before the ICC. His brief is to develop a cultural defence to exonerate the client. Dilemmas and strategies involved in this case will be shared with the students on a confidential basis.

This module is open to students interested in human rights and international criminal law. Students who are considering pursuing a career in international criminal law, which is one of the fastest growing and most dynamic fields of international law, are especially encouraged to enrol.

In ‘Capita Selecta – Selected Topics of Public International Law’, students will broaden their knowledge of international law by taking mini-modules which are intertwined with on-going research projects carried out by the lecturers. The course is divided into four sub-periods. During the first sub-period (week 7), students will write a research proposal for their master’s thesis. During the three other periods, students will take five different modules out of a range of options offered. Each module will last for three weeks and have, in principle, 10 contact hours. Within the short period of time, students will familiarize themselves with current topics and challenges that have not been addressed in depth in the General Course or other courses of the specialized tracks. Through the Capita Selecta course, students will further develop their skills to critically analyze case-law and existing literature, write short papers, present findings, and provide feedback to other students.

https://osiris-student.uu.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/176751,2017,Capita Selecta Public International Law: EU External Affairs and International Trade,English,Faculty of Law, Economics and Governance",,['dr. C.M.J. Ryngaert'],,"Course goals

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

column2: • Students will further develop the basic knowledge of the concepts of international law and EU law, which they have acquired in the General Course on Public International Law and EU law master courses
• They will familiarize themselves with basic international law on the characterisation and responsibility of international organisations
• Students will consider key questions surrounding the hierarchy of norms within the international and EU legal systems
• They will examine issues regarding the acquisition of binding international obligations by individual states and international organisations

• Students will consider more generally the evolution of international law and the EU, and critically engage with how practitioners, Member States, the CJEU and academics have constantly considered and re-considered the relationship between international law and the EU

• Students learn to distil and evaluate legal questions from existing normative debates and provide reasoned answers to them by employing persuasive analysis or arguments using analogical and deductive reasoning
• Students learn to critically approach and assess the legal questions posed
• Students develop their research, analytical, writing and oral skills.

column1: <meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

Over the past decades, the European Union’s continued integration has given it a unique character as an international actor. While the EU characterises itself as a sui generis, autonomous and supranational legal order, this approach does not necessarily align with that of international law.

This module aims to discuss some key questions surrounding the interface between international law and the legal order of the European Union. In doing so, it seeks to uncover some inconsistencies between the international and EU approaches to the working of international law on both the EU and its member states. Interesting issues in this regard include EU competence to conclude international agreements such as Comprehensive Economic and Trade Agreement with Canada and the Kyoto Protocol, participation of the EU in international organisations such as the World Trade Organization, international responsibility, data protection in EU-US relations, and the hierarchy of international norms in the legal order of both the Union and its member states. The focus of the course is on questions of international trade and trade-related public policy measures.
This module is aimed at students with an interest in both public international and European law, and invites them to reflect critically on the EU’s growing role as a global actor.

In ‘Capita Selecta – Selected Topics of Public International Law’, students will broaden their knowledge of international law by taking mini-modules which are intertwined with on-going research projects carried out by the lecturers. The course is divided into four sub-periods. During the first sub-period (week 7), students will write a research proposal for their master’s thesis. During the three other periods, students will take five different modules out of a range of options offered. Each module will last for three weeks and have, in principle, 10 contact hours. Within the short period of time, students will familiarize themselves with current topics and challenges that have not been addressed in depth in the General Course or other courses of the specialized tracks. Through the Capita Selecta course, students will further develop their skills to critically analyze case-law and existing literature, write short papers, present findings, and provide feedback to other students.

https://osiris-student.uu.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/176805,2017,Capita Selecta Public International Law: Equality and Non-Discrimination in International Human Rights Law,English,Faculty of Law, Economics and Governance",,['mr. dr. A.S.H. Timmer'],,"Course goals

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

column2: • Students will gain insight in different conceptions of equality and discrimination (e.g. formal and substantive equality; direct, indirect, and intersectional discrimination).
• Students will become familiar with non-discrimination case law of the European Court of Human Rights, as well as selected UN treaty bodies.
• Students gain skill in the conceptual analysis of law.

column1: <meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

Human rights and equality are inextricably linked. If people wouldn’t be equally entitled to all human rights, the whole idea of human rights would lose its meaning. The concepts of equality and discrimination are therefore very familiar, and seem easy to grasp. However, the more closely one studies them, the more confusing and elusive they become. What does equality mean when only one job applicant can be appointed? When is preferential treatment acceptable? Equal treatment may result in more inequality instead of less, or the other way around. Sometimes differentiated treatment may be the answer, but at the same time it may lead to stigmatization and more discrimination. Because of these difficulties, international courts and treaty bodies are clearly struggling to develop workable models to assess discrimination claims.

This module will examine the ins and outs of equality and non-discrimination in human rights law. We will discuss topical cases from the European Court of Human Rights as well as selected UN human rights treaty bodies, and explore the different conceptions of equality that underlie the case law. No specific discrimination ground will be singled out, since the focus is on equality and non-discrimination rather than on the protection of a specific group. This, moreover, allows for a comparison between the approaches to a variety of protected identity traits such as race, gender, age, disability, sexual orientation and religious discrimination. Are the different grounds for discrimination subjected to the same assessment standards?

In ‘Capita Selecta – Selected Topics of Public International Law’, students will broaden their knowledge of international law by taking mini-modules which are intertwined with on-going research projects carried out by the lecturers. The course is divided into four sub-periods. During the first sub-period (week 7), students will write a research proposal for their master’s thesis. During the three other periods, students will take five different modules out of a range of options offered. Each module will last for three weeks and have, in principle, 10 contact hours. Within the short period of time, students will familiarize themselves with current topics and challenges that have not been addressed in depth in the General Course or other courses of the specialized tracks. Through the Capita Selecta course, students will further develop their skills to critically analyze case-law and existing literature, write short papers, present findings, and provide feedback to other students.</body>

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

column2: • Students will develop a comprehensive understanding of the definition of a refugee in the light of the human rights paradigm
• Students will reflect on key challenges in the international protection regime.
• Students learn to identify and, where appropriate, distinguish the different needs for protections by an in-depth analysis of international and domestic case law
• engage in detailed analysis of a single issue of particular interest through independent as well guided research and writing

column1: <meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>
This course serves as a general introduction to International refugee law. The course includes 5 weekly lectures of 2 hours each that are ideally divided into two core learning blocks:

1) a core block on Refugee Qualification which aims to answer the key questions of international refugee law, namely: who is a refugee, what is a refugee fleeing, who cannot be anymore or deserve to be a refugee. It will address all issues related to the inclusion, exclusion and cessation clauses (crucial concepts, such as alienage, asylum, persecution, refugee protection, serious harm, will be explored and the interrelationship between IRL and IHRL will be taken constantly into consideration);

2) a core block on Complementary Protection, which will focus on subsidiary and temporary protection as especially stemming from the core obligations under the principle of non-refoulement in IRL and IHRL.

The 5 lectures will focus on the core theoretical concepts that students are required to learn to master key concepts of international and European refugee law , they will follow a practical and interactive pedagogy, including a range of activities such as learning how to search for and read refugee law materials, cases to be collectively debated and solved, screening parts of documentaries (e.g. Well-founded Fear, Fuocoammare), brainstorming session, simulations

in the moot court format with different parties to represent. To this extent, classes will provide students with an opportunity to engage with case law to reason on and apply basic theoretical concepts.
Students will be divided into groups. Each group will be “on call” for one of the weeks of the course. “On call” students have 2 particular duties:
a) identify and elaborate 2 short questions/comments from relevant Basic readings that will be submitted a few days before class and will be presented and discussed in class;
b) be prepared to take the lead in responding to questions about the cases under discussion from the week’s materials.

All students are required to write short case note(s) critically discussing on the basis of the background knowledge acquired throughout the weekly lectures how theoretical concepts translate to real world contexts.

In ‘Capita Selecta – Selected Topics of Public International Law’, students will broaden their knowledge of international law by taking mini-modules which are intertwined with on-going research projects carried out by the lecturers. The course is divided into four sub-periods. During the first sub-period (week 7), students will write a research proposal for their master’s thesis. During the three other periods, students will take five different modules out of a range of options offered. Each module will last for three weeks and have, in principle, 10 contact hours. Within the short period of time, students will familiarize themselves with current topics and challenges that have not been addressed in depth in the General Course or other courses of the specialized tracks. Through the Capita Selecta course, students will further develop their skills to critically analyze case-law and existing literature, write short papers, present findings, and provide feedback to other students.

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

column2: • Students will be able to critically engage with interconnections between human rights and the natural environment.
• Students will know about  the latest developments concerning ‘environmental rights’ at the global, regional and national level.
• Students will understand how the human rights framework functions in an ecological stressed world.
• Students will understand the underlying assumptions of the human rights framework and ecological thinking and how these influence law and policy.
• Students have further developed their analytical, oral presentation and writing skills.

column1: <meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

Human rights are considered to lay down claims of value and are supposed to experience an elevated legal status. They also seem to be changing, developing in such a manner as to deal with current issues. For this reason it is not surprising that stakeholders frame environmental claims and interests in  the language of human rights. Examples are, for instance, the Ogoni people in Nigeria which are confronted with oil spills and the US landmark constitutional climate change case ruling in favour of the interests of today’s children and against the use of fossil fuels. However, this is not without challenges as the human rights framework is often critiqued for its inadequacy in addressing injustices. Also human rights are criticized for being individualistic and disregarding the interests of others. In addition the Western conception of human rights is considered to be problematic and lacking inclusion of Global South perspectives. These arguments challenge the appropriateness of the human right framework to address (global) environmental issues. However at the different levels: globally, regionally and nationally human rights have been used as a vehicle for addressing environmental degradation. States such as Ecuador and South Africa have included constitutional rights to an healthy environment and in other states court decisions have been used to support environmental efforts.

This module is designed to explore the relationship between human rights and the environment in the  ecologically stressed world of the twenty-first century and beyond. This module discusses international human rights law, international environmental law and national laws which illustrate how states aim to tackle the general and specific environmental challenges they are confronted with. Also, particular existing human rights (both civil and political rights as well as economic, social and cultural rights) will  be analyzed on their connection to environmental issues and ‘new’ or developing rights such as the right to water, energy and clean air will be discussed.

In ‘Capita Selecta – Selected Topics of Public International Law’, students will broaden their knowledge of international law by taking mini-modules which are intertwined with on-going research projects carried out by the lecturers. The course is divided into four sub-periods. During the first sub-period (week 7), students will write a research proposal for their master’s thesis. During the three other periods, students will take five different modules out of a range of options offered. Each module will last for three weeks and have, in principle, 10 contact hours. Within the short period of time, students will familiarize themselves with current topics and challenges that have not been addressed in depth in the General Course or other courses of the specialized tracks. Through the Capita Selecta course, students will further develop their skills to critically analyze case-law and existing literature, write short papers, present findings, and provide feedback to other students.

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

column2: • students should be able to explain the key challenges in international efforts to prevent climate change and to reduce its risks;
• students should be able to illustrate how the international legal regime for climate change and related legal instruments does and does not address the key challenges of climate change; and
• students should be able to analyze a relevant issue within international climate change law in an informed manner.

column1: <meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

Climate change is presently the most difficult and important international environmental issue, and probably will be for decades to come. It is a “wicked” problem involving global collective action, transnational and intergenerational risks, and great uncertainty. Its interconnected relationship with heterogeneous economic development, both past and future, makes climate change even more complicated. This capita selecta course introduces students to international climate change law, focusing on the three global international agreements that are dedicated to reducing climate change risks: the UN Framework Convention on Climate Change, the Kyoto Protocol, and the Paris Agreement. It also uses climate change as an example of how problem structure shapes the appropriate response, and of how global governance operates through diverse legal means (i.e. treaties, institutions, soft law, interrelated domains) to encourage participation and to prevent and resolve disputes. Other important concepts, such as collective action problems, market-based instruments, and intergenerational discounting, are introduced, drawing from political science and economics to offer an interdisciplinary perspective. Finally, the course also describes some ways in which climate change relates to other international legal issues, including the oceans, human rights, and trade.

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

column2: • Students will make a start with or further develop their skills to critically question law on its assumed neutrality, and human rights law in particular.
• Students will gain knowledge on human rights law and topical gender issues.
• Students learn to identify and, where appropriate, distinguish between legal, moral, political and other considerations and arguments.
• Students develop their research, analytical, oral and writing skills.

column1: <meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

“All human beings are born free and equal in dignity and rights. They are endowed with reason and conscience and should act towards one another in a spirit of brotherhood.” Article 1 of the Universal Declaration of Human Rights, more or less provides this module’s focus in a nutshell: the universal aspirations of the document as well as the short-sightedness of its drafters in terms of gender (‘brotherhood’).

This module focuses on gender issues in international human rights law. Gender is used here in its broad meaning encompassing both male/female issues as well as LGBTI-concerns. Both issues are closely connected but are not without tensions. Some major concepts (universality, gender, equality) will be explored and applied to human rights law at three different levels: black letter law (what does the law say?), context (why is the law as it is?), and normative assessment (is the law as it should be?).

After an introduction to the relevant background and key concepts such as the equality principle and the contested universality of human rights, one or two topics (e.g. sports, the emerging ‘right to gender recognition’) will be looked into in detail.
This module is not only relevant for students with an interest in gender issues, but for everyone interested in issues of universality, human rights and discrimination.

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

column2: • Students learn how to determine whether international humanitarian law applies to a particular situation of violence
• Students learn the key principles of international humanitarian law
• Students gain an in-depth knowledge of two topics of international humanitarian law
• Students learn to analyse a particular factual situation vis-à-vis the legal framework of international humanitarian law
• Students develop their skills in legal research, analysis and writing
• Students learn to participate actively in academic discussion and oral legal analysis

column1: <meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

In the previous century armed conflict cost the lives of millions of human beings. As a result, a body of rules was developed to protect the most vulnerable groups during armed conflict and to mitigate the methods of warfare. However, a cursory look at newspapers today provides evidence of the fact that these rules are all too often violated in modern armed conflicts. The abuse and torture of prisoners of war, the perpetration of sexual violence against women and children, the destruction of cultural artefacts, the taking of hostages and the killing of civilians. These are all examples of violations of the ‘laws of war’ and many are ‘war crimes’.

The objective of this course is to teach students the basic objectives and principles underlying the law of armed conflict. The course presents the major treaties in the field and introduces the law on protected persons (traditionally known as ‘Geneva law’) and the law on the conduct of hostilities (traditionally known as ‘Hague law’). It also focuses on the geographical, conceptual and temporal scope of international humanitarian law and the law of occupation.

This course is designed for students interested in the legal regulation of armed conflict, the protection of vulnerable persons, the conduct of military operations and international criminal law. The first four sessions will consist of lectures and the final session will consist of a practical exercise. The practical exercise is designed to give students experience in applying international humanitarian law to a ‘real life’ factual scenario. The course is examined by means of two short papers in which students are required to choose from a number of topics. Students are also examined on the basis of their active participation in class.

column2: • Students will make a start with or further develop their skills to critically question the traditional concept of international peace and security and international law based on the traditional notion
• Students will gain knowledge on international law concerning the use of force (jus ad bellum), collective security, UN peacekeeping, and UN sanctions.
• Students learn to identify and, where appropriate, distinguish between legal, political, theoretical considerations and arguments
• Student develop their research, analytical, oral and writing skills

column1: <meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

International peace and security has been traditionally understood as the absence of inter-state wars. The UN’s collective security system was originally established to “save succeeding generations from the scourge of war” based upon the prohibition of the use of force by individual states. Today, however, “international peace and security” requires much more than the absence of international armed conflicts. In the UN Security Council’s practices, international peace and security can be threatened by, for instance, the serious violations of international humanitarian and human rights law, global terrorism, the proliferation of weapons of mass destruction, and the Ebola outbreak. The conceptual extension has, on the one hand, contributed to the diversification of Chapter VII measures taken by the UN Security Council. On the other hand, the emergence of new types of threats renewed controversies over the permissible scope of use of force by individual states.

This module is designed to advance the knowledge of international law in the area of international peace and security. The module encompasses both international law regulating the UN Security Council’s exercise of authority under Chapter VII of the UN Charter, and international law on the use of force by individual states (jus ad bellum). In each week, students discuss how both the UN Security Council and individual states have responded to various crises that threaten international peace and security, including those of Kosovo, Iraq, Afghanistan, and Syria.

This module is open to students with interests in the legal constraints on the use of force, UN peacekeeping, and UN sanctions. The module is also suitable for students who are interested in the theoretical critique of international security law. This module does not deal with international humanitarian law (jus in bello).

https://osiris-student.uu.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/176868,2017,Capita Selecta Public International Law: International Water Law and the Sustainable Use of Shared Water Resources,English,Faculty of Law, Economics and Governance",,['mr. dr. O. Spijkers'],,"Course goals

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

column2: • Students will gain knowledge of the general legal framework of international water law, and familiarize themselves with its main principles.
• They learn to apply this framework in a particular case.
• Students develop the capacity to write a short memorial, arguing from a particular position and interest, in a limited amount of time.
• Students learn to familiarize themselves in a short time-span with a new topic of international law.

column1: <meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

Important developments are currently taking place in international water law. The Convention on the Law of the Non-Navigational Uses of International Watercourses, the only truly global convention on international watercourses, finally enters into force. And all over the world, people are becoming aware of the importance of the sustainable utilization and management of shared water resources.

In the first lecture and working group, students will familiarize themselves with the legal framework of international water law, including the principle of equitable and reasonable use of transboundary waters, and the no-harm rule. We will also briefly introduce the case study of week 3, and divide the perspectives and roles over the students, and explain the assignment to them. This allows the students to start drafting their memorial already in the first week.

In the second week, these bedrock principles of international water law will be linked to sustainable development. We will look at the relationship between international water law and multilateral environmental agreements, as well as basic principles of sustainable development. How “green” is the Watercourses Convention and international water law?

In the third week, we will focus on a particular case study, a particular international watercourse, and apply what we discussed in weeks 1 and 2. The students all choose the perspective of one of the actors involved in the case study, and write a memorial. The students will also present the argumentation developed in their memorial in the form of oral pleadings.

column2: • McCaffrey, Stephen C., The law of international watercourses, 2nd edition, Oxford University Press, 2007.
• McIntyre, Owen, Environmental protection of international watercourses under international law, Ashgate, 2007
• Wouters, Patricia, The International Law of Watercourses: New Dimensions, Collected Courses of the Xiamen Academy of International Law, 2011

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

column2: • Students will make a start with or further develop their skills to critically question the traditional concepts of territorial sovereignty, border control and migration control
• Students will gain knowledge on international law concerning border and migration control, human rights and refugee law at sea, search and rescue operations.
• Students learn to identify and, where appropriate, distinguish between legal, political, theoretical considerations and arguments.
• Student develop their research, analytical, oral and writing skills.

column1: <meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

Migratory flows by sea are not a new phenomenon and, since the Indochinese crisis  in the Seventies, they are well known under the expression “boat people”. In the past, sea-born migratory flows consisted in isolated episodes, in emergency waves related to specific historical events . For the last twenty years arrivals by sea have however become a regular phenomenon, in particular along the coasts of the Mediterranean Sea and of Australia. The sea has then become a regular route for migration and it is undoubtedly one of the most dangerous ones.

This module is designed to advance the knowledge of international law in the area of law of the sea, human rights and refugee law. The module encompasses both international law regulating the powers of states to perform migration and border control at sea (within and without their national jurisdiction), and search and rescue services. In each week, students discuss how both destination and transit states have responded to the various migratory flows, depending on the geographical, political and historical contexts. Students also focus on the role of international organisations, such as the EU and NATO, in the management of irregular migration by sea.
This module is open to students with interests in migration and refugee law, in border control and enforcement at sea.

column1: <meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

The research module is part of the OST trajectory. It takes place in period 3 and it is an entry requirement for writing your Master thesis. See Rules and Regulations 2017-2018 and Blackboard for further regulations. Earlier in the academic year you must communicate in which discipline you want to graduate. Information about this will be communicated in a timely manner. A thesis supervisor will be assigned by the thesis coordinator of the Master by means of a completed thesis form.  In the research module students will, in addition to a research plan, provide feedback on the thesis structure of other students and give a presentation about their own structure. Attendance is mandatory. The research module is completed with an approved research plan.
Place of this course within the curriculum:

column2: • Compulsory course in master Public International Law

column1: https://osiris-student.uu.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/176680,2017,Capita Selecta Public International Law: The Impact of the International Law of the Sea on State Behaviour,English,Faculty of Law, Economics and Governance",,['dr. A.G. Oude Elferink'],,"Course goals

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

column2: • Students gain an understanding of the relationship between international law and State behavior and the factors that may explain compliance with or deviance from the law
• Students will get a better insight in how States argue international law to justify their policy choices and behavior
• Students learn to apply general concepts and models to specific cases
• Students are confronted with different explanatory models and learn to assess the explanatory value of these different models
• Students develop the capabilities and skills to research, analyze, discuss and write about the relationship between international law and state behavior from various perspectives

column1: <meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

The international law of the sea is critical to providing order for the oceans. The sovereignty of states only extends beyond their land territory over a limited belt of 12 nautical miles (approximately 22 kilometers). Beyond the territorial sea, international law provides a regulatory framework for balancing the rights and obligations of different states. A key document in this respect is the United Nations Convention on the law of the sea, also referred to as a constitution for the oceans. Contrary to what this epithet suggests, the Convention has not always been successful in shaping state behavior. At the same time, there is a large measure of compliance with many provisions of the Convention. Looking for explanations for the (lack of) effectiveness of the international law of the sea will be the focus of this course.

The question as to why states act or do not act in accordance with international law has led to many explanatory models. The present course will present a number of these models to the students. This concerns the international law as ideology perspective developed by Scott; the rational choice theory of De Guzman; and the realist perspective developed by Posner and Goldsmith. The introductory lectures will explain the basics of these models and set out the differences and similarities between them.

This course is designed for students interested in the question as to why international law matters and in the interplay between international law and international politics. Although the focus is on the law of the sea, the knowledge that has been acquired in this course can also be applied to other fields of international law. The introductory lectures will provide essential background information about the international law of the sea and then will present the three explanatory models. Following the introductory lectures, each student will be required to write a paper on case study on a specific legal conflict or legal claim that will be analyzed through the lens of one of the explanatory models. These papers will be presented and discussed during the two tutorials. Students are expected to participate actively in the discussions.

Within the short period of time, students will familiarize themselves with current topics and challenges that have not been addressed in depth in the General Course or other courses of the specialized tracks. Through the Capita Selecta course, students will further develop their skills to critically analyze case-law and existing literature, write short papers, present findings, and provide feedback to other students.

https://osiris-student.uu.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/176749,2017,Capita Selecta Public International Law: Transitional Justice in Post-Conflict Societies,English,Faculty of Law, Economics and Governance",,['dr. B.N. McGonigle Leyh'],,"Course goals

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

column2: • Students gain an understanding of the development of transitional justice and how it operates within the broader peacebuilding field.
• Students gain an understanding of the various transitional justice mechanisms adopted by States to deal with and address past human rights and humanitarian law violations.
• Students learn to identify and, where appropriate, distinguish between legal, moral, political and other considerations and arguments related to transitional justice discussions.
• Students develop the capabilities and skills to research, analyse, discuss, negotiate and write about relevant topics in the field of transitional justice.

column1: <meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

How should a society deal with a history of human rights and humanitarian law violations? Should trials prosecute those responsible? Or should a general amnesty be imposed in order to secure peace? How should the society deal with the memory of the victims and do the victims deserve financial compensation? These are some of the questions that will be touched upon in this module.

Post-conflict peacebuilding refers to actions taken to support societies trying to avoid a relapse into conflict. It is a multi-dimensional endeavor with several pillars; one of which is referred to as transitional justice. Together with other pillars, such as rule of law, security and development, it is now firmly apart of peacebuilding responses. Transitional justice arose out of the need to address widespread and systematic human rights and humanitarian law violations. It is premised on the idea that backward-looking processes, which acknowledge and address harms suffered, will help bring about more peaceful and stable societies. While there are debates about the definition, it is largely seen as “the full range of processes and mechanisms associated with a society’s attempts to come to terms with a legacy of large-scale past abuses, in order to ensure accountability, serve justice and achieve reconciliation”(UN SG report). These processes include domestic and international(ized) trials, truth commissions, historical commissions, reparation programs, vetting and lustration practices, and other efforts to promote reconciliation and memorialization. This course will focus on the variety of different justice processes that have evolved over the past decades, which aim at (re-) establishing trust in government institutions, furthering reconciliation and acknowledging the harms suffered by victims.

This module is designed for students interested in peacebuilding, rule of law, human rights, societies in transition, different conceptions of justice and international politics. The course includes foundational lectures on the theories and elements behind transitional justice, including the various transitional justice processes and mechanisms favored by States. In week 1, students will have two lectures on transitional justice processes. During this week, students will be broken up into teams, each representing a different party in the simulation assigned to a specific theme. The teams will meet to work out their strategies and will start drafting their individual simulation plans. In week 2, there will be one lecture and the start of simulations.  In week 3, students will conclude the transitional justice simulation and have a debrief with the instructor. During the module, they will be required to turn in their simulation position papers, negotiate their positions during the simulation, and fill in an evaluation after the simulation.

In ‘Capita Selecta – Selected Topics of Public International Law’, students will broaden their knowledge of international law by taking mini-modules which are intertwined with on-going research projects carried out by the lecturers. The course is divided into four sub-periods. During the first sub-period (week 7), students will write a research proposal for their master’s thesis. During the three other periods, students will take five different modules out of a range of options offered. Each module will last for three weeks and have, in principle, 10 contact hours. Within the short period of time, students will familiarize themselves with current topics and challenges that have not been addressed in depth in the General Course or other courses of the specialized tracks. Through the Capita Selecta course, students will further develop their skills to critically analyze case-law and existing literature, write short papers, present findings, and provide feedback to other students.

https://osiris-student.uu.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/185189,2017,Capita Selecta Public International Law: Transnational Corporations and Human Rights,English,Faculty of Law, Economics and Governance",,[],,"Course goals

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>
<body>After this course, students will be able to:

column2: • Demonstrate up-to-date knowledge of the various takes on the corporations/human rights conundrum and of the variety of hard and soft law mechanisms for addressing the issue.
• Discuss theories of personality/subjectivity under international law in respect of private corporations.
• Critically assess the paradigm changes in international human rights law as a response to the advent of globalization.
• Critically assess the role of international criminal law in establishing the responsibility of corporations for their implication in gross human rights abuses
• Critically assess the doctrines of extraterritorial jurisdiction and forum non conveniens in respect of domestic legal remedies against transnational corporations.
• Students learn to identify and, where appropriate, distinguish between legal, political, theoretical considerations and arguments

column1: <meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

Few legal entities have attracted as much academic commentary in the past two decades as transnational corporations. Praised as vehicles for development and –at the same time– decried as harbingers of humanitarian and environmental disaster, transnational corporations have proliferated in number, as well as scope of operations, generating concern about the capacity of sovereign states to control them.

The trends towards lifting barriers to trade and creating a regulatory environment conducive to foreign investment, coupled with that of privatizing services, are eroding the omnipotence of the sovereign state. Scholars nowadays, routinely lament the fact that corporate groups dwarf developing States in terms of economic power. What is more, corporations are handed a pass to enter into what has traditionally been described the ‘public service’, thus challenging the State also functionally. Everything seems to be outsource-able to the corporation: from healthcare and the provision of water to prisons, to war.

The crux of the problem lies herein: when it comes to transnational corporations, with power does not always come responsibility. Whereas corporate power grows, and alongside it grows the capacity to inflict harm, the capacity to seek redress for such harm always appears to be waning. Human rights activists are quick to point at cases, where the implication of corporations in human rights abuses has gown unanswered, such as the involvement of Shell in the plight of the Ogoni people, culminating in the execution of Ken Saro Wiwa, the implication of Union Carbide in the Bhopal Chemical disaster, the admission by Nike of exploiting child labour in sweatshops in Pakistan and Cambodia. The reasons for which corporations evade responsibility are numerous, and they relate first and foremost to their complex structure and their economic leverage. In some cases, the problem is not that home states are unable to control the operation of a transnational corporation. Rather, in a number of cases, developing States, with the hope of luring in investment and generating revenue (often appropriated by the ruling elite) collude with corporations in the perpetration of human rights abuses. Unsurprisingly, the victims of these abuses are voiceless, without any measure of redress or remedy before a court, domestic or international.

From the perspective of international law, the corporations/human rights conundrum highlights the limitations of traditional concepts of the international law vernacular, whilst opening up the possibilities of reconsideration and re-imagination. Indeed, the proposition that corporations should be bound by human rights law and that in turn they should incur responsibility under international law raises a host of fundamental questions: are transnational corporations subjects of international law, and if not how are they to be bound by it? What is the role of human rights in a globalized economy? Should human rights operate horizontally between individuals and corporations? When a corporation and a State co-operate in the perpetration of human rights abuses, who should be held responsible under international law? Are corporate entities criminally liable, and if so before which court should they be prosecuted? And finally, and most significantly, is it by means of international law that this problem is to be solved?

The purpose of this workshop is dual. On the one hand, it aims at introducing students to the debate concerning the human rights duties/obligations of corporations. At the same time, it will use this debate as a leitmotiv, whilst revisiting key concepts or principles of international law, such as personality, attribution of conduct, interpretation, ‘softness’/‘hardness’ of law.

During the three other periods, students will take five different modules out of a range of options offered. Each module will last for three weeks and have, in principle, 10 contact hours. Within the short period of time, students will familiarize themselves with current topics and challenges that have not been addressed in depth in the General Course or other courses of the specialized tracks. Through the Capita Selecta course, students will further develop their skills to critically analyze case-law and existing literature, write short papers, present findings, and provide feedback to other students.

https://osiris-student.uu.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/185188,2017,Capita Selecta Public International Law: The Compulsory Jurisdiction of International Courts and Tribunals,English,Faculty of Law, Economics and Governance",,"['L.N. Nguyen, LLM']",,"Course goals

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

column2: • Develop a good understanding of the concept of ‘compulsory jurisdiction’ exercised by international courts and tribunals, as well as its significance under international law;
• Distinguish the ways in which the ICJ and the UNCLOS tribunals assert and exercise compulsory jurisdiction, the promise and limits of each mechanism;
• Understand and critically appraise controversial legal issues connected with ‘compulsory jurisdiction’;
• Connect theoretical issues with recent developments in international dispute settlement and are able to reflect on the implications of these developments on international law

column1: <meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

The proliferation of international courts and tribunals in the past decades has reshaped the international dispute settlement scene and posed significant challenges to the conventional wisdom that international law suffers from a weak judicial system. This phenomenon manifests itself both quantitatively in the establishment of a growing number of international courts and tribunals in various different fields, as well as qualitatively in the changing scope and nature of the jurisdiction that is invested upon them.

This module focuses on the qualitative aspect of the phenomenon, and more specifically, on the trend to confer ‘compulsory jurisdiction’ to international courts and tribunals. The module looks in detail at the ways in which international courts and tribunals exercise compulsory jurisdiction in practice, focusing on the International Court of Justice (ICJ), a universal court, and the tribunals established under the United Nations Conventions on the Law of the Sea (UNCLOS), a specialised mechanism. The module uses the examination of the cases before these dispute settlement bodies as the departure point to identify controversial legal issues arising from the existence and exercise of their compulsory jurisdiction.  Some of the questions to be addressed include: does the exercise of compulsory jurisdiction by third-party dispute settlement bodies undermine the cardinal principle of State’s consent to judicial settlement? Does the exercise of compulsory jurisdiction by an international court, especially when contested by the respondent States, impact the authority and legitimacy of international courts and tribunals? Is there a correlation between compulsory jurisdiction and State compliance? Does the exercise of compulsory jurisdiction by different courts and tribunals lead to the fragmentation of international law?

This module builds on the general course in Public International Law and  the compulsory course in the specialisation Law of the Sea. It is intended for students who are interested in international dispute settlement, particularly in inter-State adjudication and arbitration. While the focus is on the International Court of Justice and the dispute settlement procedures of the UNCLOS, the module aims to help students gain a broader picture of their role and limitations of international courts and tribunals in the age of judicialisation, as well their interaction with States and with one another.

During the three other periods, students will take five different modules out of a range of options offered. Each module will last for three weeks and have, in principle, 10 contact hours. <meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>
<div>At the end of the course the student is:

column2: • familiar with the breadth of topics covered in regional science, including those at its scientific frontier;
• able to see events in an evolutionary perspective;
• able to apply describe and understand pressing issues of sustainability, (urban) real estate and uneven growth, applying a healthy mixture of economic and geographic insights.

column1: The following aspects of academic research, reporting and effective oral presentation skills are covered in the course:

column2: • you learn to employ geographical-economical reasoning on a variety of new topics in a creative yet clear manner;
• you set up a research proposal combining different strands of literature;
• you are able to interpret the outcomes of a simplified geo-economic model;
• you are able to perform a hedonic pricing analysis.
• you effectively write out the findings of assignments.

column1: <meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

<body>Large differences exist in economic wealth and economic dynamics between countries and regions. Economic activities tend to concentrate in certain areas. We tackle this issue at several spatial levels and by adopting views from different disciplines. We start by looking at success and failure of countries and regions, and theories of convergence and divergence. We proceed with the famous Krugman “core-periphery” model, for which he won the Nobel prize in 2008. We then turn to the cutting edge field of evolutionary economics and its geographical applications. In particular, we take a geographical look at the position of the so-called third world in the current globalized world. Next, we consider an often undervalued branch of spatial economics, but one which has large implications for today´s urban world: that of real estate. A section on the role of the environment and sustainability in economics and geography completes the course. The course thus covers the current issues at the intersection of economics and geography, and it will feature a range of guest lectures by key specialists in their field.</body>

column2: • Comprehension of the complexity and data structure of diffusion MRI. Knowledge and application of simple algorithms to extract information from the data.

column1: <meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

This course covers a number of state-of-the-art techniques and topics in medical image analysis. It is a specialisation course for those with a general understanding of medical image analysis looking to deepen their knowledge. The topics of this year are

column2: • Deep Learning
• Image Registration and Validation

column1: You will learn about machine learning, (convolutional) neural networks and how to train them. The second part of the course considers nonlinear image registration and proper methods to set up a validation study. Each part of the course will come with a large group assignment on actual medical data to give you hands-on experience, both in a deep learning approach to a medical image analysis problem and in nonlinear image registration for clinical data.
Slide hand-outs, Deep Learning by Goodfellow, Bengio and Courville; other material will be made available

column1: <meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

This course consists of two independent topics. During the first half of the course researchers from the Hybrid Imaging group will introduce the following topics:

column2: • Spectral/dual-energy CT

column1: During practical sessions students will improve their understanding of the above topics, e.g. by carrying out Monte Carlo simulations, programming of a simple image reconstructor for SPECT and working on pharmacokinetic data.

The second half of the course covers theory and practice of processing, analysing and visualising diffusion MRI data. Key concepts and practical considerations of data processing and analysis are explained. Topics include

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

column2: • heeft de student kennis van en inzicht in het materieelstrafrechtelijk legaliteitsbeginsel en zijn deelnormen.

• kan de student het materieelstrafrechtelijk legaliteitsbeginsel in zijn Europese context plaatsen en de betekenis daarvan duiden, alsook de vergelijking maken met de rechtspraak van de Hoge Raad en dat evalueren.
• heeft de student inzicht in de argumenten en de argumentatiestructuur van een wetenschappelijke tekst.
• kan de student materiaal (o.m. regelgeving, literatuur en rechtspraak) verzamelen en beoordelen.

• kan de student een uitspraak van de strafkamer van de Hoge Raad analyseren en evalueren op de betekenis daarvan voor het materieelstrafrechtelijke legaliteitsbeginsel en aangeven of en hoe bepaalde deelnormen van dit beginsel toepassing vinden.

column1: <meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

Het materieelstrafrechtelijk legaliteitsbeginsel van artikel 1 Sr pleegt de hoeksteen van het strafrecht te worden genoemd. Een hoeksteen in de overdrachtelijke zin, namelijk datgene waarop alles rust. Het legaliteitsbeginsel fundeert strafrechtelijke aansprakelijkheid en overheidsoptreden om die strafrechtelijke aansprakelijkheid te effectueren. Het materieelstrafrechtelijk legaliteitsbeginsel omvat een viertal deelnormen die het optreden van wetgever en rechter normeren. In deze module komen deze deelnormen aan bod en wordt behandeld wat de deelnormen inhouden en hoe de rechter daarmee in de praktijk omgaat.

Tegen de achtergrond van de ontwikkelingen in het strafrecht (gebruik van open normen, preventief strafrecht, gelede normstelling, Europeanisering etc.) rijst – wederom – de vraag wat de betekenis van het materieelstrafrechtelijk legaliteitsbeginsel is in en voor het hedendaagse strafrecht. In het licht van de Europeanisering moet voorts aandacht worden besteed aan het legaliteitsbeginsel neergelegd in artikel 7 EVRM en de rechtspraak van het Europees Hof van de Rechten voor de Mens (EHRM) daarover.

In een vergelijking van het nationale materieelstrafrechtelijke legaliteitsbeginsel en de invulling van artikel 7 EVRM door het EHRM daarvan zal ten slotte de rechterlijke interpretatievrijheid, maar ook de noodzaak tot interpretatie van een wettelijk voorschrift aan bod komen.
Algemene informatie over Capita Selecta I en Capita Selecta II
Capita Selecta I (10 EC) en Capita Selecta II (5 EC) zijn zogenaamd ""carrouselvakken"", waarbinnen u in totaal zes modules volgt.

Capita Selecta I begeeft zich wat onderwerpen betreft in de kern van het strafrecht en het strafprocesrecht. Daarnaast biedt de cursus ruimte om op actualiteiten in te gaan dan wel thema’s multidimensionaal te benaderen. De master Strafrecht wil studenten goed voorbereiden op de arbeidsmarkt. Beroepen als advocaat, officier van justitie en rechter vergen een gedegen en diepgaande kennis van zowel het materiële strafrecht als het strafprocesrecht. Capita Selecta I bevat daartoe twee clusters van elk vijf modules, waarbij u verplicht bent om twee materieelstrafrechtelijke modules en twee strafprocesrechtelijke modules te volgen en met goed gevolg af te ronden.

Alle modules duren drie weken, waarvan twee weken onderwijs en één toetsweek. De onderwijsvormen en de toetsing verschilt per module en is aangepast op het thema en de opzet van de module. In de twee weken onderwijs gaat u meteen de diepte in in het specifieke, afgebakende thema van de module. Daarbij wordt van u verwacht dat u zelf materiaal verzamelt, dat u actief en goed voorbereid participeert in het onderwijs, dat u zichzelf bijspijkert als bepaalde basiskennis zou blijken te ontbreken. Een module vergt daarmee veel zelfstudie. Aldus wordt u in elke module kort, maar diepgaand ‘ondergedompeld’ in een bepaald thema. Daarmee verwerft u op specifieke terreinen veel kennis, alsmede de vaardigheid om op een bepaald thema snel in te werken en de diepte in te gaan. Dat is iets wat u later als advocaat, rechter, officier van justitie e.d. ook moet kunnen.

Doordat binnen het verband van Capita Selecta meer modules op materieelstrafrechtelijk en strafprocesrechtelijk terrein worden aangeboden, kunt u modules kiezen die aansluiten bij persoonlijke belangstellingen. De modules kunnen jaarlijks wisselen. Elke module is 2,5 ECTS. Dit jaar worden de volgende modules aangeboden:
Het cluster van modules op materieelstrafrechtelijk terrein (waaruit twee modules moeten worden gekozen):
Module 1 Sr: Materieel strafrecht: Materieelstrafrechtelijk legaliteitsbeginsel (RGMUSTR100)
Module 2 Sr: Materieel strafrecht: Preventief strafrecht  (RGMUSTR101)
Het cluster van modules op strafprocesrechtelijk terrein (waaruit eveneens twee modules moeten worden gekozen):
Module 1 Sv: Strafprocesrecht: Het strafvorderlijk legaliteitsbeginsel (RGMUSTR104)
Module 3 Sv: Strafprocesrecht: Modernisering wetboek van strafvordering (RGMUSTR106)
Module 4 Sv: Strafprocesrecht: De positie van het slachtoffer (RGMUSTR107)
Module 5 Sv: Strafprocesrecht: Verdieping forensische psychiatrie en psychologie in context (RGMUSTR112)

Capita Selecta II ziet op het verwerven van verschillende soorten vaardigheden. Het betreft vaardigheden die voor de rechtspraktijk van groot belang zijn. Daarbij wordt uitgesplitst naar de rechtspraktijk in de vorm van de togaberoepen en de rechtspraktijk in de vorm van onderzoeksfuncties. Voor beoefenaren van de togaberoepen is van groot belang dat zij beschikken over uitstekende mondelinge vaardigheden vooral in de vorm van pleiten. Dat is wat advocaten doen bij hun pleidooi en wat officieren van justitie doen bij hun requisitoir. Daarom wordt in Capita Selecta II een module over het schrijven en het houden van een pleidooi en/of requisitoir aangeboden, de module Praktijkopdracht.

Echter, niet alle studenten komen uiteindelijk in togaberoepen terecht. Zij verwerven vaak functies met een onderzoekscomponent. Bovendien hebben studenten soms belangstelling voor het doen van wetenschappelijk onderzoek. Om die reden wordt ook een module onderzoeksopdracht aangeboden. Maar ook hier is het geven van een presentatie onderdeel van de toetsing.
Ten slotte maakt de module Onderzoeksopzet scriptie onderdeel uit van Capita Selecta II. Hierna komt deze voor alle studenten verplichte module verder aan bod.
Na afloop van Capita Selecta I:

column2: • heeft de student diepgaande kennis van en inzicht in een aantal deelterreinen van het straf(proces)recht.

• heeft de student kennis van en inzicht in de wisselwerking tussen Europese en internationale ontwikkelingen en van het straf(proces)recht,  en is in staat om de internationale en nationale maatschappelijke context van het straf(proces)recht mee te wegen in de analyse van dat rechtsgebied.

• is de student in staat om zelfstandig en in korte tijd diepgaande kennis en inzicht te verwerven in een vraagstuk of onderwerp op het terrein van het straf(proces)recht, mede met het oog op het professioneel functioneren op de arbeidsmarkt.

• is de student in staat om zelfstandig bestaande wetenschappelijke kennis op integere en methodologisch verantwoorde wijze te vergaren, deze op waarde te schatten en daarop kritisch te reflecteren en deze op systematische wijze te verwerken en te ordenen, ongeacht of de bronnen van deze kennis in het Nederlands of in het Engels zijn gesteld.

• kan de student kennis, ideeën, oplossingen en conclusies alsmede de argumenten, motieven en overwegingen die hieraan ten grondslag liggen, zowel schriftelijk als mondeling begrijpelijk, gestructureerd, correct en overtuigend communiceren aan een publiek van specialisten en niet-specialisten.

• is de student is in staat theorie en praktijk met elkaar te verbinden in het bijzonder door een analyse te maken van en oplossingen aan te dragen voor juridische kwesties die in de praktijk spelen aan de hand van de theoretische kennis en inzichten die zijn verkregen.

column1: Na afloop van Capita Selecta II:

column2: • heeft de student kennis van en inzicht in een onderwerp behorend tot het straf(proces)recht.
• kan de student een straf(proces)rechtelijk leerstuk in context plaatsen.
• kan de student een onderzoeksvraag formuleren en uitwerken in deelvragen en heeft hij een goedgekeurde opzet voor zijn scriptie opgesteld.
• kan de student materiaal (o.m. regelgeving, literatuur en rechtspraak) verzamelen en beoordelen.
• kan de student een opzet voor zijn masterscriptie structureren en opstellen, en de opzet schrijven in helder en correct Nederlands.
• kan de student een coherent betoog opbouwen, schrijven en presenteren, op basis van  een heldere juridische argumentatie, uitdrukken.

• kan de student juridisch redeneren en schrijven (duidelijke opbouw, structuur en conclusies) en daarvan schriftelijk verslag doen in een paper geschreven in helder en correct Nederlands waarbij men zich doeltreffend kan uitdrukken.
• kan de student individueel een luisterwaardig betoog houden, op basis van een zelf geschreven processtuk of paper.

column1: Een module heeft een andere opzet en moet door iedereen worden gevolgd. Dat is de module Onderzoeksopzet scriptie (RGMUSTR010). Deze module strekt tot het schrijven van een definitieve, goedgekeurde opzet voor de masterscriptie. De module vormt het sluitstuk van het OST-traject. Het is het eindresultaat van de derde fase in het OST-traject (zie het document Onderzoeks- en scriptietraject Master Strafrecht 2017-2018, te vinden op de Blackboardomgeving van de module). Voor de module Onderzoeksopzet scriptie ontvangt u geen cijfer, maar een voldoende of een onvoldoende.  Als u een voldoende haalt, kunt u aanvangen met het schrijven van de masterscriptie onder begeleiding van de scriptiebegeleider die u reeds in het OST-traject is toegewezen. Bij een onvoldoende kunt u niet beginnen met het schrijven van de masterscriptie. U zal de module Onderzoeksopzet scriptie moeten repareren door alsnog een scriptieopzet in te leveren die met een voldoende kan worden beoordeeld. Voor meer informatie over de module zie het Studiebulletin van de module Onderzoeksopzet scriptie dat op de Blackboardomgeving van de module beschikbaar is gesteld.
Wanneer is aan de vereisten van Capita Selecta I en Capita Selecta II voldaan?

Aan de vereisten van Capita Selecta I (10 EC) is voldaan zodra uit Osiris blijkt dat u twee materieelstrafrechtelijke en twee strafprocesrechtelijke modules met succes heeft behaald. Aan de vereisten van Capita Selecta II (5 EC) is voldaan, zodra uit Osiris blijkt u een voldoende heeft behaald voor de module Onderzoeksopzet scriptie alsmede een voldoende heeft behaald voor ofwel de module Praktijkopdracht, ofwel de module Onderzoeksopdracht.

Periode 3 is onderverdeeld in drie blokken van drie weken. De modules van Capita Selecta I en Capita Selecta II worden verspreid over deze blokken van drie weken aangeboden. De module Onderzoeksopzet scriptie wordt alleen in het eerste blok van drie weken aangeboden en moet, als gezegd, door iedereen worden gevolgd. Voor de andere modules geldt dat daarvoor kan worden ingeschreven. Vanwege de verplichting om twee materieelstrafrechtelijke modules en twee strafprocesrechtelijke modules met goed gevolg af te ronden, moet u een zodanige keuze maken uit het aanbod van modules dat u in staat bent om aan deze verplichting te kunnen voldoen. Dat kan betekenen dat u in een blok drie modules moet volgen, terwijl u in een ander blok twee modules volgt.

Let op: voor de modules geldt een maximumcapaciteit van 25 studenten. Schrijf derhalve zo snel mogelijk in en geef voorkeuren aan. U wordt in modules geplaatst. Het kan zijn dat u niet kan worden geplaatst in de module van uw eerste voorkeur.

Voor elke module geldt dat een reparatie- of inhaalmogelijkheid bestaat. Deze reparatie- of inhaalmogelijkheid geldt specifiek voor de module en de docent van de desbetreffende module bepaalt wat de reparatie- of inhaalmogelijkheid inhoudt en wanneer die plaatsvindt (dat kan in periode 4 zijn, vooral bij modules van het derde blok). Raadpleeg derhalve het studiebulletin van de desbetreffende module over de reparatie- of inhaalmogelijkheid. Als u een module moet repareren, kunt u voor de reparatietoets van die module maximaal een zes (6) behalen.

Mocht u in periode 4 gebruik (moeten) maken van een reparatie- of inhaalmogelijkheid, dan heeft dat invloed op uw scriptieplanning. Eventuele vertraging die u oploopt bij het schrijven van uw scriptie is uw eigen verantwoordelijkheid. De scriptiedeadline blijft onverkort gelden.
