<head><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>
<body>

column4: The course looks closely into the area of psychology concerned with the study, diagnosis, and treatment of abnormal behavior or psychological disorders. It examines the leading theories of why people develop problems, focusing on how each theory has led to a distinct approach to therapy.

The class integrates didactic, interactive, and participatory methods. Two sessions are held weekly. The first session consists of a topical lecture, which is followed by class discussion. In the second meeting, the class engages in various activities. Students view films that demonstrate experienced practitioners at work with patients, varying modes of clinical intervention, and issues in diagnosis and treatment. They also discuss the readings, role-play, and work in small groups so to gain experimental knowledge of the various tools of effective clinical psychologists.

Students prepare to participate actively in lecture by completing weekly reading assignments. They write a final paper and present their findings to the class. They also take a midterm and final exam.

column2: </body>

column1: https://osiris-student.uu.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/180107,2017,Clinical Skills & Clinical Encounter,Dutch,Faculty of Medicine,,['dr. S.C. Bakker'],,Content

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

The content of the CSCE program focuses on the teaching and training of medical-technical skills (clinical skills) and basic communication skills (clinical encounters). This program consists of two parts. Part 1 includes the period until the Entrance Examination Student Clinics and part 2 the period until the Final Examination CSCE.
The objectives of the CS program are:

column2: • To be able to perform a basic physical examination in a clinical setting
• To correctly report the findings of a basic physical examination in the patient's medical history.
• To perform basic resuscitation on medical phantoms according to the NRR (Dutch Resuscitation Council)-protocol
• To develop other medical skills such as injecting pharmaceuticals and wound care.

column1: The main requirements for performing a basic physical examination will repeatedly be covered throughout the year. These are:

column2: • Professional conduct: professional attitude of the physician during the consultation with the patient; this is simulated during each teaching session
• Anatomy in vivo: paying attention to live human anatomy
• Reliability of the findings
• Interpretation of the findings
• Recognition of pathological findings

column1: The objectives of the CE program are:

column2: <li>To learn important skills of the clinical encounter: exploring, structuring, and leading of doctor-patient communication.
<ul>

column3: • This is thought for all phases of the consult: identification of the patient’s main question, planning diagnostics and the medical plan.

column2: • To professionally structure the doctor-patient (or doctor-colleague) relationship in order to establish trust and to manage conflicts.
• To demonstrate empathy and respect for the opinions and emotions of patients and colleagues.
• To strive for a doctor-patient relationship based on equality. Retaining personal responsibility as a physician while allowing the patient to influence decision-making.

column1: The CS program consists of 19 sessions. During each session, as much time as possible is devoted to practicing skills. E-modules prior to teaching sessions will provide background information.  In many of these sessions students will practice skills either on each other or on medical phantoms. When practicing on each other is required, every student is expected to be willing to act as a ‘patient’. For this purpose the student may have to partially undress.
A practice examination session is held in preparation for the Entrance Examination Student Clinics (SP) and the Final Examination CSCE.
Most of the sessions have a duration of three hours. These sessions will be attended by a group of either 10 or 20 students, supervised by a physician/clinical skills instructor.

Throughout the academic year, students have the opportunity to independently practice the learned skills (docent onafhankelijk trainen, DOT; [Instructor Independent Training]) in specially equipped KVO (Klinisch Vaardigheids Onderwijs, KVO [Clinical Skills education]) classrooms. Students must make reservations for practice time in these classrooms through a Blackboard-based online registration.

A separate monthly CS-consultation is provided for students who wish to discuss content-related questions or to practice skills with a KVO-teacher. For this, preregistration is required. Preregistration is possible at the KVO desk on the third floor of the Heijmans van den Bergh building. It is also possible to ask fellow students and KVO-teachers a question via the digital discussion forum in Blackboard.

The CE program consists of 10 three-hour sessions. The course includes the following themes: respectful attitude and confidence-building, posing questions expertly, active listening and understanding, interpreting non-verbal communication, clarifying the symptoms and the main complaint, exploring and managing emotions, and conducting results/ 'bad news' consultations
Clinical skills are developed using several work forms: role-play exercises in subgroups, mandatory sessions with fellow students and simulated patients, DVD recordings of simulated patient contacts.
Each subgroup consists of 10 students. CE instructors are behavioral scientists. A practice examination session is held in preparation for the CSCE final examination.

Additionally, a separate monthly CE-consultation exists for students who wish to discuss content-related questions with a KVO-teacher. For this, preregistration is required. Preregistration is possible at the KVO desk on the third floor of the Heijmans van den Bergh building.

Two CSCE integration sessions are scheduled before the start of student clinics. During these sessions, a full medical consultation is simulated in order to practice integrating CS- and CE-skills. This includes identification of plausible diagnoses. The full medical consultation is practiced either with fellow-students or simulated patients; this includes integrating the information obtained from the medical history-taking and the physical examination, in order to summarize the information, and explain plausible diagnosis. During these lessons, both physicians and behavioral scientists are present as instructors.
The clinical skills and clinical encounters sessions begin during week 1 (calendar week 36) of year 1, and comprise part of the educational steam Clinical Practice.
The course handbook includes check-lists, sample reports, and E-modules for the CS-sessions and is available on Blackboard. The content of the CS-instruction is based on the following sources:

column2: • De Jongh TOH, Buis J (red.). Fysische diagnostiek. 2015 Bohn, Stafleu van Loghum With films (mandatory textbook)
• De Jongh TOH, Buis J, Daelmans HEM, Dekker MJ, De Loor JD. Praktische vaardigheden 2012; Stafleu van Loghum  ISBN 9789031388974. With films (recommended textbook)
• Additional recommended literature for specific lessons can be found in the course handbook.

column1: The course handbook for the CE-instruction is also available on Blackboard. The content of the CE-instruction is based on the following:
Silverman J, Kurtz S en Draper J. Vaardig communiceren in de gezondheidszorg: een evidence-based benadering. Lemma, 2014 ISBN 978‐94‐6236‐359‐5
In order to be allowed to participate in the CS- and CE-assessments the conditions regarding attendance and study requirements (up to the assessment) must have been met.

A practical examination takes place twice during the academic year: The Entrance Examination Student Clinics part 1 of CSCE), and the Final Examination CE/CE (part 2 CSCE). Students demonstrate the acquired abilities and are observed and assessed by instructors. Detailed information pertaining to the structure, content and organization of practical examinations are available on Blackboard (including assessment forms).

Drs. Abel van de Ven, Coordinator and Instructor CS / Medical Technical Skills,  Department of Clinical Skills training, mail: a.vandeven-5@umcutrecht.nl; Drs. Maaike Kok, coordinator and instructor CE/ Communication skills, Department of Clinical Skills training, mail: M.Kok-5@umcutrecht.nl
Examiner Drs. Jacqueline van Wijngaarden, Head of  Clinical Skills department room HvdB 3.10, tel. 088-7551421/ 088-7559589 (secretariat), e-mail j.j.vanwijngaarden-3@umcutrecht.nl
https://osiris-student.uu.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/177142,2017,Clinical Track,English,Faculty of Social Sciences,,['dr. W.W. Hale'],,Course goals

column2: <head><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>
<body>

column3: The aim of the course is to familiarize the student with: - theoretical underpinnings of several prototypic evidence based treatments - certain issues surrounding the dynamics between assessment of psychosocial problems and treatment evaluation and - some of the statistical, methodological and social issues that concern the empirical evaluation of evidence based treatments. At the end of the course the students should be able to assess evidence based treatments in the broadest sense of the word, designs their own treatment study, and discuss the main theoretical, methodological, and statistical issues (i.e, the inherent pros and cons) that are debated in the current literature on these studies. Many times children and adolescents are at risk for deviant developmental pathways. A considerable number of children and adolescents actually develop these deviant developmental pathways, often resulting in distress to themselves (psychosocial problems) and to their home environment. When the youngster has developed psychosocial problems (ranging from light to severe), evidence based treatments are available that aim to reduce these psychosocial problems or to help the person cope with the consequences of these problems. Therefore, the objective of this course is to familiarize the student with the theoretical underpinnings of several prototypic evidence based treatments, certain issues surrounding the dynamics between assessment of psychosocial problems and treatment evaluation and some of the statistical, methodological and social issues that concern the empirical evaluation of evidence based treatments. The student will discuss the pros and cons of the statistical and methodological issues, and not simply repeat a dogmatic standpoint of a particular scientific group.</body>

column1: <head><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>
https://osiris-student.uu.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/184106,2017,Clinical Trials,Dutch,Faculty of Medicine,,['dr. P.A.H. van Noord'],,Content

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>
Examiner:              Dr. G.C.M. van Baal                                   Timeslot: BC
“It is unethical to let human subjects participate in research that has not been designed carefully and sound”.

A sound methodological-statistical design is an essential condition for the reliability of the results of a (clinical) study. In the course we will pay attention to the most important aspects of the design of a phase III, randomised clinical trial (RCT) to compare two treatments of patients with the same disorder. These aspects are, amongst others, different ways of randomisation and stratification, determination of the necessary number of patients, the data processing and statistical analyses, the interpretation and publication of trial results.

In the course we will also discuss regulatory issues researchers will have to deal with in the design and execution of a comparative clinical trial. We will pay attention to skills necessary for the education to Clinical Research Associate and/or clinical investigator.
Students will write a research protocol in small groups coached by the teachers and a clinical investigator. One or more guest lecturers will present topics based on their own (practical) experience.

Knowledge of introductory statistical methods is required (descriptive statistics, both graphical and quantitative; statistical tests for the comparison of two independent groups with dichotomous or continuous outcomes, such as a chi-square test, t-test, and non-parametric tests; statistical tests for paired dichotomous or continuous observations);
Knowledge of statistical software, preferably SPSS.
After the course the student will be able to describe:

column2: • the most important methodological concepts of clinical trials, such as randomisation, blinding, use of placebo, necessity of a control group, sample size en further aspects of the design of a phase III randomised clinical trial;

• to which organisational aspects a clinical trial will have to comply, such as Good Clinical Practice, Law on Medical Research with Humans, and which of these are important (responsibilities, side effects, drug accountability, monitoring, etc.).

column1: The student will be able to

column2: • apply the acquired theoretical knowledge by writing a research protocol for a comparative phase III clinical trial;
• calculate the sample size for the most frequent experimental designs and apply simple statistical analyses on the results of a phase III trial;
• phrase and explain the contents of the conceived research protocol.

column1: The student will be able to:

column2: • give a logical argumentation with respect to the ethical aspects of participation in a clinical trial.

column1: In the self-directed learning time students will have to prepare the theory (reading a chapter in the textbook and/or a literature article) and work on the study protocol. During the contact time the studied theory will be discussed. In computer labs statistical analyses will be practiced.

Students will draft a research protocol for a clinical trial in small groups. The protocol will be presented towards the end of the course to their fellow-students, clinical investigators, epidemiologists and biostatisticians.
The course will have 30% of contact time at most. During the contact hours and computer labs students will have to be present.

The final grade is an average of the judgements based on the individual contribution to the theoretical discussions during the contact hours; the participation in the course; the presentation of a case study; the presentation of the study protocol and the response to questions about it; the judgement by the clinical investigator; the interim exam and the final, individual exam about the theory and the protocol.

column2: • The text book 'Fundamentals of Clinical Trials' (4e ed., 2010) by L.M. Friedman e.a. ( can be borrowed on payment of € 15);
• The course manual (€ 10), in which practical information and literature is included;

• ’Internationaal richtsnoer voor Good Clinical Practice voor onderzoek met geneesmiddelen (translation to Dutch)’, ICH guideline for Good Clinical Practice E6 and ‘Clinical research with medicinal products in the Netherlands. Instruction Manual’;
• Literature with respect to the contents of the study protocol.

column1: https://osiris-student.uu.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/181135,2017,Clinical psychology,English,Faculty of Social Sciences,,['dr. A.D. Williams, PhD']",,"Course goals

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

At the end of this course students should be able to critically evaluate the literature in the field and discriminate between empirical and unsupported claims, integrate knowledge of basic processes (e.g., effective communication) and apply this understanding to their own professional work (i.e., in their internship), reflect on the practical and ethical consequences of adopting new health care strategies, identify the barriers and challenges of translating research findings into practice, and critically appraise their own professional responsibilities as future researchers or practitioners in the fields of Clinical Psychology.

The course learning objectives will be assessed through written and oral assignments that require integration of material presented in the lectures and working groups. Students will be required to critically appraise the relevant literature and formulate arguments that support their position on topical issues in the field of Clinical Psychology.</body>

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

During this course various topical issues that are relevant to scientific research and practice in Clinical Psychology are addressed. These issues relate to broader themes that students will encounter during their internship and thesis, and when working as a professional in the domain of Clinical Psychology.
Central themes for the course could include the following:
Reach and Participation: How to reach people who need psychological help and how to stimulate participation and adherence.
Professionalism in health care: How to keep academic knowledge up to date and practice according to sound ethical principles.
Critical scientific thinking: How to distinguish science from pseudoscience and how to recognize potentially harmful interventions.
Effective communication: How to convey evidence-based knowledge to patients/clients, the community, and policy-makers.

Each of these issues will be addressed in lectures that will provide both a theoretical orientation and an applied focus (i.e., providing students with examples from practice). Students are required to reflect critically on these topics and to consider the relevance of these issues for their own research work (in the context of their master's thesis) and practical work (in the context of their internship). The working groups will be interactive in nature (e.g., a debate or student presentation) and require active participation of students.
https://osiris-student.uu.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/177783,2017,Close Reading: Meaning and Form,Dutch,Faculty of Humanities,,['C. Aaftink, PhD', 'dr. J.J.M. van Stralen']",,"Course goals

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

<body>De studenten leren werken met literairwetenschappelijke methoden van close reading, inclusief die uit de verhaal- en poëzieanalyse. Zij leren deze methoden toepassen op verhalen en gedichten. De studenten leren de theorie van literaire mechanismen begrijpen en de vaardigheid om primaire bronnen nauwkeurig te lezen. Zij kunnen de theorie van literaire mechanismen toepassen op primaire bronnen en een literaire analyse presenteren in woord en schrift.</body>
<head><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

Dit casuscollege is     gericht     op     het     aanleren     van     de     methode     van     close     reading     in     het     proces     van     literaire     analyse     en     interpretatie.     Studenten     leren     de     grondbeginselen     van     de     narratologie,     poëzieanalyse     en     de     hermeneutiek.     Ze     doen     dit     aan     de     hand     van     een     reeks     verhalen     en     gedichten     door     de     tijd     heen.

column2: <body>

column3: In the internships of master year 1 and 2 discipline-bound deepening and intensification of content takes center stage. The learning outcomes for the internships of the bachelor phase apply to the internships in master year 1 and 2 as well, but on a higher level:

column5: Learning to work ‘independently’ while taking some responsibility
Greater mastery of discipline-related content

column3: The internship takes six weeks fulltime and depending on the internship placement, is alternately spent in the outpatient ward, emergency ward and clinic. A professional training day takes place once a week (on Friday) for discipline-bound training and Conceptual Reasoning in Medicine.

Strictly speaking, a part of the education taking place on the professional training days is part of the internship itself. The other part is Conceptual Reasoning in Medicine which is an independent longitudinal programme running parallel to the internships.

column5: Six professional training days: each Friday from 10 am.
Mornings: Discipline-bound education Surgical topics
Afternoons: Conceptual Reasoning in Medicine (see the CRM course materials)

column3: The following topics are alternately covered during the Discipline-Bound training (general overview):

column5: Vascular surgery: AAA’s, carotis/extracranial vascular surgery
Plastic surgery: closure of wounds: from primary via skin transplantation to free flap, burns, hand surgery and possibly mamma-surgical aesthetic/reconstructive
Urology: Oncological ailments of bladder and prostate, fertility, gynaecology, nephrology, geriatric; in consultation with the students
Orthopaedics: examination of locomotor system, arthroscopy, research/lab
General: treatment of wounds, fractures, acute abdomen, thorax injuries
Mouth diseases / surgery: Oral / Maxillofacial surgery

column3: ·         ‘Clinical reasoning’ (DD, examination plan, interpretation of results, indication for surgery (or lack thereof!), therapeutic plan)
In consultation with the (programme)coordinator/examiner, the supervisor and the International Office it is possible to conduct the internship Surgery II abroad.

The Manual ‘Internship Surgery II’ contains a wealth of information about the organisation and content of the internship and the internship placements. The Manual and the Portfolio Module are available from Willy’s Winkeltje. For teachers, a teacher manual is available from the secretariat of the internship in the UMC Utrecht. This reader contains general information regarding the internships CRU as well as the Blueprint 2001.
Multiple teachers are involved in the final assessment. Three assessment moments contribute to the final grade:

column5: Midterm interview guided by the portfolio
Final interview (week 6) guided by the portfolio, in which is included the
Assessment of professional behaviour.

column3: The final grade consists of these separate assessments and the grade will be rounded up to one digit after the decimal point according to the rules of the exam commission.
Dr. I.Q. Molenaar, coordinator, tel: 088 755 58512, pager 3564, e-mail: i.q.molenaar@umcutrecht.nl
André Renaud, staff member education DHS, tel: 088 755 6962, e-mail: onderwijs-heelkunde@umcutrecht.nl

column2: </body>

column1: <meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

The general objectives of       the       internship       is       to       get       to       know       the       field       of       dermatology       in       practice,       refresh        and       expand       previously       acquired       knowledge       and       skills       and       apply       these       in       the       clinical       setting.       After       the       completion       of       the       internship       Dermatology       the       intern       should       be       able       to       take       a       complete       history       and       conduct       dermatological       examinations.       The       intern       also       has       to       be       able       to       come       to       a       differential       diagnosis,       recognize       the       most       common       dermatological       and       venereal       clinical       pictures       and       should       have       gained       insight       in       the       diagnostics       and       therapeutic       treatment       options.

The duration of the       internship       is       two       weeks       preceded       by       the       connected       preparatory       course       Dermatology       of       two       weeks.        The       preparatory       course       consists       of       interactive       lectures       in       small       groups.
The internship       Dermatology       directly       follows       after       the       preparatory       course       Dermatology       in       master       year       2.

Many titles from the       general       mandatory       book       list       are       relevant       for       this       internship,       in       particular       Dermatology,       David       J.       Gawkrodger       and       “       “Dermatologie       en       venereology       in       de       praktijk”,       A.       de       Groot       en       J.       Toonstra

The course book       dermatology       and       the       ‘Manual       Internship       Dermatology       year       5’       contain       a       wealth       of       information       about       the       organization       and       content       of       the       preparatory       course,       the       internship       and       the       internship       placements.       The       course       book,       the       manual       and       the       portfolio       have       been       placed       on        Blackboard       and       are       also       available       from       Willy’s       Winkeltje.
Two assessment moments       contribute       to       the       final       grade:
-                The       preparatory       theoretical       course       (presentation,       input/effort,       final       test):       33%
-                Final       interview       portfolio:       level       of       clinical       reasoning       and       technical       skills:       67%
There are three       additional       requirements       in       order       to       pass       the       internship:
-                Professional       behaviour       should       be       of       sufficient       level
-                The       grade       of       the       test       in       the       theoretical       course       should       be       sufficient

-                2       brief       practical       assessments       Clinical       Consult       and       1       brief       practical       assessment       Technical       Skill       need       to       have       been       conducted

The final assessment       consists       of       the       separate       assessment       moments       described       above.       According       to       the       rules       of       the       exam       commission       a       weighed       average       grade       will       be       calculated       and       the       grade       will       be       rounded       up       to       one       digit       after       the       decimal       point.

column2: <head><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>
<body>

column3: The objective of the internship Ear, Nose and Throat is to expand theoretical knowledge of ENT and learn in practice. A number of skills specific to the field of ENT medicine, such as examinations, diagnostic methods and treatments, are trained.

The internship ENT has a duration of four weeks in total. These four weeks are divided in a course week and three weeks in the clinic. During the course week you are prepared for the clinic through ENT case-histories, Meet-the-Expert-sessions on basic ENT and audiometry and an anatomy lab session. This offers you the chance to refresh the basic knowledge of the field of ENT in one week. Self-study is required.

The course week is concluded with a course test on basic ENT. The course week must be concluded with a sufficient assessment, before you can follow the clinical internship of three weeks. The internship KNO may be done in the UMC Utrecht as well as the affiliated hospitals.
In the second year of the master CRU2006.
Leerboek Keel-, Neus- en Oorheelkunde, edited by E.H. Huizing and G.B. Snow. Published by Bohn, Stafleu & van Loghum. Most recent edition.
Zakboek Keel- en Neus- en Oorheelkunde, edited by P. van der Broek and L. Feenstra. Published by Acco Leuven/Leusen. Most recent edition (recommended).

The manual ‘Course week ENT and internship ENT’ and the portfolio module contain a lot of general information about the organization and the content of the internship and the internship placements. The manual and the portfolio module are available from Willy’s Winkeltje or via Blackboard and need to be in the student’s possession at the start of the course week. The student will also receive the most recent information, the time tables and an activity schedule at the start of the course week via the educational secretariat.

Assessment takes place in the UMC Utrecht and the affiliated hospitals. The final grade for the internship ENT is a weighed average grade (rounded up to 1 digit after the decimal point) and consists of three test moments. Each test moment counts towards the final grade of the internship.

column5: Theoretical course (course test in course week)
1. Patient-demonstration/EBCR: 20%
Final portfolio interview: 20%
Taken into account: Brief Practical Assessments-clinical consults (KPB’s)
Taken into account: Patient reports
Final interview subject-related knowledge: 60%

column3: Going abroad and non-affiliated hospitals in the Netherlands

In case a different (or extra) internship placement is desired in or outside the country, the student has to organize this him- or herself. To gain permission the student needs to provide (written) evidence from the prospective hospital/the supervisor at the intended internship placement and a completely filled out application form ‘domestic/international internship’ (available from the educational secretariat ENT: d.houtkamp@umcutrecht.nl ; tel. 088 7556644). Both documents have to be handed in by the student to the educational secretariat ENT. After this, the educational coordinator ENT from the UMC Utrecht will decide whether to grant permission for the internship.

When the student conducts an internship for which permission has been granted in a non-affiliated hospital in the Netherlands, Belgium or Luxemburg, the intern will be assessed by the supervisor of that internship placement on subject-related knowledge, three sort brief practical assessments, patient reports and professional behaviour. The usual assessment forms will be used for these assessments. The supervisor will sign off the final interview and the final grade for the internship on the final assessment form. This form, including the professional behaviour assessment form, has to be handed in at the educational secretariat ENT in the UMC Utrecht.

When the student conducts an internship for which permission has been granted outside of the Benelux, the intern will be assessed by the supervisor of that internship placement on subject-related knowledge, brief practical assessments, patient reports and professional behaviour. For these assessments the English assessment forms obtainable from the educational secretariat ENT should be used. The final grade for the internship on the final assessment form will not be signed off in the hospital abroad. Upon return the student has to hand in all English assessments plus a compensatory assignment at the educational secretariat ENT within two weeks. The compensatory assignment will be assessed by the educational coordinator ENT of the UMC Utrecht. All assessments (from abroad and the UMC Utrecht) together will determine the final grade for the internship.
The final grade for the internship is determined by the educational coordinator ENT UMC Utrecht. This will be recorded on the final assessment form internship ENT CRU.
Coordinator:         Mrs. drs. I. Ligtenberg-van der Drift, ENT-physician UMC Utrecht, e-mail: I.Ligtenberg-vanderdrift@umcutrecht.nl

column1: <meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>
Heleen van Ravenswaaij Msc, Biomedical Sciences.
Heleen and Michele developed this elective course in co-operation with Career Services.
A diverse groups of lecturers and professionals from the educational and corporate world will share their knowledge and skills during this elective course

As a bachelor year 3 / master student of the University Utrecht (UU) you are not far away from graduating, taking your first steps into the professional world. You will be challenged to work with a diverse group of colleagues, co-operate, and solve complex problems that fit users and society’s needs. This implicates that you need insights in how to grow as a professional in a fast changing world, be able to attain the right knowledge and skills.
Gaining new skills implicates the ability to actively plan, reflect, learn and experience your way into these skills to keep on track in a world where ‘life-long learning’ has become the standard.

This two-week elective course offers you a challenge to create a concept for a client in co-operation and co-creation with peers from several bachelor (year 3) and master programmes and professionals from the educational and corporate world. You are offered short inspirational sessions and workshops to discover which team- and individual based (soft)skills, techniques and tools are needed to deliver a concept. At a networking event you will pitch the concept and receive feedback. Several coaches are available if you need help (on-demand coaching). You will present your final concept to the client and a jury using a pitch and a report.

You will create an elevator pitch. Being able to pitch your own unique set of skills can assist you in your future employability. Therefore, a coach will guide you through the process of making this pitch, and you will hand in a video of the pitch
This course is inspired on a co-creation event EduChallenge. A video of this challenge can be watched on: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=_iyCVDV9ACw
For more detailed information visit the website www.co-challenge.nl
You can apply for this course by sending an email to Michèle Gerbrands (info@co-challenge.nl).
Available full time (9:00- 16:30)  during the course: O yes/ O No
Short motivation (1 A4 page) why you want to participate, addressing the following topics:

column2: •  What is, according to you, entrepreneurship?
•  What do you think you can learn from this course and what do you expect in general?
• What do you think you can offer your peers in this course (in terms of knowledge, skills, personality etc.)?

column1: Mandatory for students in own Master’s programme:
Optional for students in other GSLS Master’s programme:
There is a limit of 25 students. Registration is on first come, first served basis (max. 6 students per bachelor/master) if the applicant will meet the following criteria:

column2: • You are available (full time) during the course (9:00-16:30).
• Short motivational letter why you want to attend this elective course.

column1: Every master student and bachelor year 3 from the UU can participate in this elective course. The theme of this real-world problem you will be solving is Healthy Urban living. You will be developing a concept for the City of Utrecht. A detailed description of the assignment will be presented online before the start of the course and face-to-face on day 1 of the course.
The course will be offered in English.

A detailed schedule will be online before the start of the course and handed at the first meeting. We will start every day at 09:00 a.m. with an informal activity and end around 16:30 p.m. On day 4 the day ends at 18:30 p.m. due to the networking event.</body>

<head><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>
facilitate         individual         and         group         activities         aimed         at         personal         and         professional         development;
apply         basic         communicative         skills         in         (individual)         coaching         and         (group)         training         activities;

carry         out         a         methodically         justified         individual         coachingprocess         and         deliver         a         methodically         justified         training;
collect         feedback         in         a         systematic         way         and         reflect         on         your         actions         as         coach         and         trainer.

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

Coaching       and       training       is       all       about       facilitating       learning       for       individuals       and       groups/teams.       The       knowledge       and       skills       that       are       necessary       for       coaching       and       training       are       important       for       academic       professionals       who       are       going       to       support       co-workers       or       clients.       Coaching       is       directed       at       fostering       self-directed       learning       and       personal       growth.       The       coach       aims       at       enlarging       problem       solving       and       self-regulating       skills       of       individuals       or       teams.       Coaching       is       more       about       asking       the       right       questions       than       telling       people       what       to       do.       Coaching       involves       working       towards       the       goal       the       coachee       has       set       for       him-       or       herself       in       collaboration       with       the       coach.       Training       involves       designing       a       learning       environment       (the       workshop)       for       a       group       and       to       subsequently       deliver       this       workshop       to       the       target       audience.       A       workshop       aims       at       activating       the       participants       to       acquire       knowledge,       understanding       and       skills       with       regards       to       a       given       subject.       When       this       is       done       in       an       effective       way,       the       workshop       facilitates       change       to       achieve       individual       and       organizational       goals.       The       course       gives       the       opportunity       to       acquire       experience       with       coaching       and       training.       Students       are       asked       to       take       on       the       different       roles       of       coach       and       coachee,       of       trainer       and       workshop       participant,       because       the       change       of       perspective       will       lead       to       a       deeper       understanding       of       effective       coaching       and       training.       The       theoretical       knowledge       about       coaching       and       training       helps       you       to       place       your       experiences       in       a       wider       scope       of       reference       and       provides       a       framework       to       reflect       on       your       learning       process.       Theory       is       used       as       a       source       of       inspiration       for       the       coaching       process       and       workshop       design       and       it       is       used       to       attain       a       well-founded       self-reflection.       Theory       and       practice       combined       lead       to       your       own       perspective       on       coaching       and       training.

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>
Na afronding van deze cursus heeft de student:

column2: • geleerd te functioneren in de rol van coach en in deze rol meer procesgericht dan oplossingsgericht leren coachen;
• geleerd te coachen vanuit de methodiek van ‘Organizational role analysis’;
<li>inzicht verworven in case-management van intake tot afronding, de fasen in het coachingsproces, het belang van coachingsrelatie als bron van informatie en het omgaan met weerstand;
<ul>

column3: • de eigen gespreksvaardigheden verder ontwikkeld en verdiept;
• kennis en inzicht verworven in verschillende coachingsmethodieken;

column2: • kennis en inzicht verworven op het gebied van coaching als vorm van personeels-ontwikkeling.

column1: <meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

De vaardighedencursus ‘Coaching in Organisaties’ legt een belangrijke basis voor je ontwikkeling in de rol van coach. In deze cursus maak je kennis met de praktijk en theorie van coaching van medewerkers in organisaties en leer je te werken vanuit het psychodynamisch en systemisch perspectief op het coachingsproces.

We werken hiervoor met de methodiek Organizational Role Analysis, zoals die door The Grubb Institute en anderen is ontwikkeld. Centraal in deze methodiek voor coaching en consulting staat de analyse van de ervaringen van de gecoachte medewerker in zijn/haar rol in een organisatie en procesgerichte advisering.

Tijdens de cursus verkrijg je kennis en vaardigheden via concrete ervaringen en reflectie hierop. Om de specifieke vaardigheden van de coach aan te leren, krijg je onder andere training in gesprekstechnieken, in het werken met de methodiek, leer je hoe een coachingstraject eruit ziet en zijn er literatuurbesprekingen. Daarnaast ga je ook zelf een coachingstraject uitvoeren met een externe cliënt  waarin alle facetten (van intake tot afronding, de fasen van het coachingsproces, het belang van de coachingsrelatie en het omgaan met weerstand) aan bod komen. Je wordt hierin begeleid door ervaren coaches in de vorm van supervisie.
Aan het eind van de cursus lever je een portfolio in dat de volgende zaken bevat:

column2: • een reflectie op de ervaringen tijdens de workshop  Organizational Role Analysis; werken met de ‘organization-in-the-mind’;
• een case beschrijving van het eigen coachingstraject met daarin een beschrijving van de eigen leerervaringen en ervaringen tijdens de supervisie;
• een bespreking van twee thema’s uit de literatuur;
• een kritische bespreking van coaching management tool.

column1: Deze vaardighedencursus wordt in de tweede weekhelft, vanaf woensdagmiddag geroosterd.

https://osiris-student.uu.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/177430,2017,Coaching psychology and consulting psychology: Applied social and organizational psychology,Dutch,Faculty of Social Sciences,,['dr. M.D. den Ouden'],,Course goals

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

Systematisch kunnen ontwikkelen en toepassen van succesrijke interventies met gebruikmaking van algemene gedragstheorieën, algemene veranderingstheorieën  en specifiekere veldkennis,met name gericht op individuen en groepen in een organisatiecontext.

Inhoudelijke kennis ontwikkelen met betrekking tot een aantal van de belangrijkste interventieparadigma's en interventietechnieken, zoals die worden gebruikt op het gebied van coaching en consulting. Inhoudelijk-toegepast leren coachen - op inleidend niveau - vanuit/met een aantal van de belangrijkste interventieparadigma's en interventietechnieken, zoals die worden gebruikt op het gebied van coaching en consulting.

De gekozen toetsvormen - een combinatie van een tentamen en een individuele opdracht die met hulp van een groep wordt gemaakt-  zorgt ervoor dat inhoudelijke kennis wordt getoetst en dat men in een groep systematisch werkt aan de ontwikkeling van een interventie, waarvan uiteindelijk een individueel verslag wordt gemaakt. Daarmee wordt op individueel niveau ook de toepassing van kennis inclusief interventieparadigma’s en –technieken getoetst.

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

Hoe stimuleer je individuen, groepen/teams en organisaties om zich effectief te ontwikkelen in diverse – vaak veranderende –contexten? Welke psychologische theorieën kun je gebruiken om hun gedrag beter te begrijpen en welke evidence-based interventies kun je inzetten?

In deze cursus leer jij de basiskennis en de basisvaardigheden van 'theory- and evidence-based' psychologisch interveniëren: het domein van coachingpsychologie en consultingpsychologie. Deze kennis is cruciaal voor aankomend psychologen die in de praktijk willen gaan werken als psycholoog-coach, psycholoog-trainer of psycholoog-consultant  (“scientist-practitioner”). Het is een onderdeel van het bredere veld van Applied Psychology (toegepaste psychologie): het zinvol benutten van de wetenschap voor praktijksituaties. Kern van dit blok is dat je een systematische manier aanleert om wetenschappelijke en ervaringskennis te ontsluiten en te benutten voor interventies.

Veel psychologische interventies zijn ingebed in een bepaald paradigma, zoals het positief psychologische paradigma of het cognitief-gedragsmatige paradigma. Deze paradigma's en daarop gebaseerde interventies zullen de revue passeren en daarbij ook de shift in denken die heeft plaats gevonden in psychologisch interveniëren: van denken vanuit deficiëntie (klassieke 'klinische' paradigma's) naar denken vanuit kracht (positieve psychologie).

In het practicumgedeelte ga  je in een team met een zelfgekozen thema aan de slag om een kansrijke interventie te ontwikkelen voor een specifieke probleemsituatie. Daarbij ontwikkel  je een  systematische, ecclectische en pragmatische methode van gedragsbeïnvloeding waarbij wetenschap altijd het vertrekpunt is om een interventie vorm te geven.

column4: The duration of the internship in general practice is six weeks. The first week consists mostly of an introduction course and the next 5 weeks will consist of clinical training in the general practice.  Students return to the UMC on Fridays for a so-called professional training day. The mornings are dedicated to the medical process in the general practice and the afternoons to the longitudinal program Conceptual Reasoning in Medicine (Diagnosis-Epidemiology-Prognosis-Therapy = DEPTh training). The objective of DEPTh-training is to gain a better understanding of the clinic by using additional knowledge from the basic courses (especially physiology, pharmacology, anatomy, laboratory results, microbiology).

During the Introduction Course there will be 9 lectures, 8 interactive lectures, 7 group sessions  and 4 self study sessions , which vary from 30 to 90 minutes. On the Professional Training Days there will be 1 lecture, 2 interactive lectures, and 9 group sessions , which vary from 60 to 120 minutes. The DEPTh training consists of 3 afternoons of 3 hours of blended learning.

The objective of the internship in general practice is formulated by the Inter-faculty forum general practice (‘Interfacultair Overleg Huisartsgeneeskunde, IOH-b) as follows: “Through the internship in general practice the intern is enabled (independently but under supervision) to  experience, contemplate and understand what it means for a general practitioner to interact with patients, their complaints, their illnesses and problems in relation to their living environment and what it means to have to deal with the uncertainties a general practitioner encounters”.
-       To gain insight in the incidence and prevalence of (frequent) complaints and illnesses
-       To gain insight in the difference between the complaint and the (im- or explicit) request for help
-       To gain insight in the Diagnostic, Etiologic, Prognostic and Therapeutic way of thinking and acting
-       To learn to register consults and home visits in the general practice registration system (H.I.S.)
-       To gain insight in the personal factors of the general practitioner and the patient influencing their mutual relationship and way of (inter-)acting
-       To gain insight in and knowledge of other forms of primary medical aid
-       To distinguish patterns of cooperation within the primary medical aid sector and between  the primary and secondary medical aid sectors (i.e. hospital environment)
-       To enable the future newly graduated physician to choose a suitable profession
-       To gain sufficient knowledge and understanding of general practice to cooperate adequately with general practitioners in the future.
The choice of assignments, the program of the professional training days and the way in which assessment is conducted are characterized by these objectives.
-       De Jongh, T.O.H., de Vries, H., Grundmeijer, H.G.L.M. Diagnostiek van alledaagse klachten, 2nd revised edition B.S.L. Houten, 2005.
-       Grundmeijer, H.G.L.M. et al. Het geneeskundig proces. Elsevier/Bunge, Maarssen, 3rd entirely revised edition 2009 (recommended literature)
Many books from the general mandatory book list are also relevant to this internship. A list of recommended literature will be distributed at the start of this internship.
Because of the unique position of the general practice  in the Dutch health care system, it is not possible to do the internship abroad.

The work book accompanying the internship in general practice contains information about the organization and content of the internship and the internship placements. You will receive the manual and the portfolio module before the start of the internship.

At least two teachers are involved in the final assessment, which are: the general practitioner-teacher (‘huisartsdocent’, HADO) in whose general practice the internship takes place and the general practitioner-group supervisor. There are three assessment moments:

-       Midterm interview with the HADO (GP-teacher), assessment of professional behavior and assessment of medical reasoning and acting (as a general practitioner) (this does not contribute to the final grade)
-       Final interview (week 6) with the HADO, in which the assessment of professional behavior and medical reasoning and acting are included (80%)
-       Evaluation by the group supervisor based on the assignments and the participation in the group (20%)
The final grade is composed of the separate assessments described above. In accordance with the rules of the exam commission the final grade is rounded up to one digit after the decimal point.

NB: Due to the restricted number of internship placements it is possible to look for your own internship placement under certain conditions. Please contact Mrs. I.C. Laurens or Mrs. M.P.T. Pot (onderwijs-huisartsgeneeskunde@umcutrecht.nl)
Examiner Clinical phase General Practice:  Mrs.D.L.M. Zwart, MD,  D.Zwart@umcutrecht.nl

<body>

column4: The intern can only start the internship after the course Medicine and Society – preceding the internship – has been successfully completed. The internship should be followed immediately after the course Medicine and Society. In case the student wishes to deviate from this rule, permission from the coordinator is required and the period of time between the completion of the course Medicine and Society and the start of the internship cannot exceed 3 months.
It is not allowed to organize an internship  yourself because of affiliation agreements made with the training institutions in the OOR-region.

The objectives of the internship in social medicine are to bring the social-medical way of thinking into practice, to obtain social-medical skills and practical knowledge and to gain an overview of the total field of social medicine. The latter is mostly achieved through the presentations and meet-the-expert sessions on the professional training days.

Internships are allocated by draw at the start of the course Medicine and Society. Should you wish to learn more about the internship you can find  relevant information in the manual about the internships.
The duration of the internship is four weeks. The intern is present at the internship location from Monday to Thursday. The professional training days take place on Fridays.

On the professional training days, Meet-the-Expert sessions (MTEs) will take place, just like presentations sessions and working lectures (part of the Conceptual Reasoning in Medicine (‘TLO’) educational program) in the second, third and fourth week. The theme of the Conceptual Reasoning in Medicine program during this internship is patient safety, which is an important part of the MD-program. Attendance of at least 80% of the professional training days is mandatory as described in the Education and Exam Regulations (‘OER’).
The internship takes place in the second year of the master directly after the course Medicine and Society.
Mackenbach & Van der Maas: Volksgezondheid en gezondheidszorg, zesde druk (2012). This book is also mandatory literature for the course Medicine and Society
Per internship place additional mandatory literature is given, which the intern needs to study before starting the internship.

The internship Social Medicine can be followed abroad. In that case, the student needs to organize the internship himself and ask permission from the coordinator in advance. Please contact the educational secretariat for this: Mrs J. Munsterman, phmstude@umcutrecht.nl. Permission needs to be obtained at least two months before the start of the internship. Preceding the internship the student will take part in a preparatory meeting “Internships abroad”.
A checklist for internships abroad is available from Mrs J. Munsterman (contactable on Mondays and Fridays) or the website of the Medical Faculty (http://www.uu.nl/studenten/geneeskunde).
The internship is divided into four content areas:
- Society & Health: including youth health care, infection prevention and control, forensic medicine and general social medicinmedicine.
- Work & Health: including occupational medicine, insurance medicine and sport medicine.
- ‘Care’: multidisciplinary care, including addiction care, elderly medicine, mental disabilities medical care and rehabilitation medicine.

For the internships a separate manual is available in which the content of the internship is further specified. The manual can be obtained from Willy’s Winkeltje during the course Medicine and Society.
Assessment of the internship takes place on the basis of:
- The assessment of the assignments. Final interview with internship supervisor at the place of internship at the end of week 4, guided by the portfolio (40% of final grade).
- Assessment of the intern’s functioning in the practice of the internship by the internship supervisor at the end of week 4 (40% of final grade).

Professional behavior is included in this assessment. A midterm interview takes place at the end of week 2 and a final interview at the end of week 4. Professional behavior must be sufficient in order to pass the internship.
- Presentation held by the interns about their internship (20% of final grade). This presentation is assessed by teachers during the professional training days.

The final assessment is composed of the separate assessments described above. The assessment forms can be downloaded from Blackboard. The final assessment form is available at the Student Information Point (STIP) or Willy’s Winkeltje. At the last day of your internship, you hand in these forms with your name, student number and group number. The downloaded forms have to be completed by your local internship supervisor. The final assessment form will be signed by the examiner of the Department of Public Health, Julius Center.
Mr R.W. Haneveld, MD, MSc: Public Health Physician, policy and advice, social-medical consultancy, insurance medicine.
Mrs E. de Leeuw, MD, Msc: Public Health Physician, policy and advice, social pediatrics and forensic medicine.
Mr. E. Stigter, MD, MSc: Occupational Health Physician, occupational and insurance medicine.
Mrs I.J.E.M. Swaans, MD, MSc: Public Health Physician, social pediatrics.
Mrs E. de Leeuw, MD, MSc, Public Health Physician
Mrs E. de Leeuw, MD, MSc, Head of the Educational,Department of Public Health, contact via education secretariat: Mrs. M.C. van Straaten, phone 088-7559306, email phmstude@umcutrecht.nl.

column1: https://osiris-student.uu.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/179739,2017,Coastal Morphodynamics,English,Faculty of Geosciences,,['prof. dr. B.G. Ruessink', 'prof. dr. P. Hoekstra']",,"Course goals

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>
At the end of this course, the student has:

a. obtained a generic understanding of the natural and human-induced factors, processes and morphological features that determine the short-term and long-term behaviour of coastal sedimentary systems;

b. determined the different spatial and temporal scales associated with coastal morphodynamic behaviour and has the ability to qualify and quantify the interrelations between processes and form evolution;
c. become familiar with terminology, and with approaches, methodologies and tools for coastal research;
d. developed skills to critically read recent scientific results as presented in the literature; and,
e. the ability to synthesize this knowledge (a-d) in realistic case studies.</body>

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

This course focuses on the estuarine, coastal and marine processes and morphological features that determine the morphodynamic behaviour of coastal systems. Coastal morphodynamics is defined as the mutual co-adjustment of coastal landforms and processes. Emphasis is on the behaviour of sedimentary coastal systems, such as beaches and dune coasts, barrier island systems, tidal inlets, estuaries and deltas. It includes the behaviour of both sandy and muddy coasts. The time scales involved vary from less than a second (e.g., intra-wave processes; short-term) to decades (e.g, the coastal response to sea level rise; long-term).

The course starts with the dynamics of wave-, tide- and current-driven processes and the effect on sediment transport processes and associated morphological change. The second part of the course deals with the morphodynamic character of different types of coastal systems. This is analysed by discussing, evaluating, and quantifying the dominant processes, the relevant morphological features and sedimentary products. Exercises, papers, and a case study are an integral part of the course and will be used to develop skills in analysing and solving coastal problems.  The course also contains several lectures on coastal instrumentation (for example, remote sensing) and on the societal relevance of coastal processes in mitigating coastal erosion.
The course contributes to the following transferable skills:
• Written communication skills: individual reports on exercises, papers and case study
• Problem-solving skills: answers to a series of questions related to a coastal case study using limited, predominantly graphical information.

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

column2: • important cognitive processes, the most common models of human emotion, and related notions such as engagement, motivation, and (social) presence;
• evaluation of the cognitive and emotional response of ICT users;
• prespectives such as Affective Computing and Emotional Design;

column1: and the ability to apply this knowledge in the design and evaluation of various kinds of applications.</body>

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

In this course we will cover cognitive processes (such as observation and processing information, and using and storing it), emotions, and  their interrelationship. Focus is in the role of these phenomena in the desing and use of ICT.

Traditionally, cognition and emotion are treated separately in research literature. The mutual dependence of emotions and cognitive processes is however obvious, and clearly relevant for the design and evaluation of many computer applications: e.g., systems that help users making decisions in stressfull situations, training applications where virtual characters show emotions, and games that are entertaining and educational. Also, in common applications emotions and cognitive proceses of the user are involved: when an application provides too much information, the user will make errors and get frustrated.  A well-designed application, on the contrary, affords the user a pleasant working experience.
The course is relevant for students interested in (applied and entertainment) games, and  human-computer interaction in general.

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>
Na afloop van het theoretische deel van deze cursus kan je:

column2: • onderzoek naar de verschillende cognitieve capaciteiten van organismen uitleggen en toepassen en ook de relatie leggen tussen cognitieve capaciteiten en het sociaal functioneren van organismen,
• het biologische concept persoonlijkheid en het onderzoek erover uitleggen en toepassen
• kritisch evalueren van methodes die cognitieve capaciteiten van dieren testen.

column1: Verder heeft de cursus ten doel de synthese van een wetenschappelijke methode zoals beschreven bij de vaardigheden.

column2: • analyseren van primaire literatuur
• bedenken/synthese van wetenschappelijke methode voor een experiment over een cognitieve vaardigheid op basis van literatuur en creativiteit (‘experimental design’), resulterend in:
• een  verslag (in het Engels) met wetenschappelijke literatuur
• mondelinge rapportage (in het Engels)
• inhoudelijke discussie voeren
• ethisch bewustzijn

column1: <meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>
Niveau 1 cursussen Biologie van dieren en Evolutie en biodiversiteit, of vergelijkbare kennis.
De cursus is een kerncursus in het studieadviespad Gedragsbiologie en een vervolg op de cursus Gedragsbiologie die aansluit bij de track Behavioural Ecology in de master Environmental Biologie.
De cursus is een verdere verdieping van het gedeelte Gedragsbiologie in de niveau 1 cursus Biologie van dieren en van niveau 2 cursus Gedragsbiologie.

Het hoofdthema van de cursus is cognitieve vaardigheden, met de nadruk op sociale cognitieve vaardigheden. Voor het functioneren van individuen in groepen zijn bepaalde cognitieve vaardigheden vereist, van eenvoudige herkenning tot 'theory of mind', afhankelijk van de complexiteit van groepen en omgeving.

De cursus begint met cognitieve ethologie (intentie, deceptie, theory of mind, episodisch geheugen), en vervolgens wordt ‘consciousness’ besproken. Aan bod komen verder communicatie en taal, spatiale oriëntatie, sociaal leren (imitatie, emulatie; innovatie; culturele transmissie en ‘tool use’) en de ‘evolution of the mind’. Daarnaast wordt persoonlijkheid bij dieren behandeld.

Het theoretische deel eindigt met een discussie naar aanleiding van het boek ‘Hoe denken dieren’ van Virginia Morell, dat van te voren kritisch gelezen is, en op basis van de kennis opgedaan in de cursus. Hiervoor dient  elke student twee discussievragen per hoofdstuk aan te dragen. De theorie wordt vervolgens getoetst middels een schriftelijk tentamen.
In het theoretische deel zal door middel van verplichte werkcolleges expliciet aandacht worden gegeven aan hoe wetenschappelijk artikels zijn opgebouwd.

Tijdens het tweede deel van de cursus wordt aan de hand van een onderwerp met behulp van literatuur en eigen creatief denken een methode bedacht om een cognitieve capaciteit van een diersoort te onderzoeken (‘experimental design’). Hierover wordt een verslag geschreven en een presentatie gegeven. Door de presentaties van je medestudenten maak je kennis met de verschillende onderzoeksmethoden voor het aantonen van cognitieve vaardigheden bij dieren.
De cursus met variaties in werkvormen van face-tot face contact onderwijs, creativiteit en discussie, tot zelfwerkzaamheid past in de 21st century skills.
Hoorcolleges, werkcolleges, discussie; verslag, presentaties; zelfstudie, lezen primaire literatuur.
Actieve deelname aan de werkcolleges over de artikels en presentaties is verplicht,

column2: • De onderwerpen van de hoorcolleges en werkcolleges worden in een theoretische schriftelijke eindtoets getoetst.
• Het verslag en de presentaties worden afzonderlijk beoordeeld.

column1: Het eindcijfer van de cursus is  de theoretische toets (60%) en het ‘experimental design’ (40%), bestaande uit de cijfer voor het verslag (2/3) en de presentatie erover (1/3).
Het eindcijfer kan alleen berekend worden als alle deelcijfers voldoende zijn.

Hierbij zal zowel aandacht besteed worden aan de theoretische achtergrond van gedragstherapeutische technieken zoals deze momenteel in de jeugdhulp gebruikt worden, als aan de inhoud en effectiviteit van deze technieken.

column1: <meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

column4: Doel van deze cursus is om meer inzicht te verkrijgen in onderliggende mentale processen die een rol spelen bij het ontstaan en in stand blijven van psychiatrische stoornissen. De cursus 'Cognitieve neuropsychiatrie' is er op gericht inzicht te geven in het werkveld van de neuropsycholoog binnen de psychiatrie. Per hoorcollege wordt een psychiatrische stoornis behandeld waarmee de neuropsycholoog in aanraking kan komen, zowel in een klinische als wetenschappelijke setting. Per stoornis wordt aandacht besteed aan de symptomatologie, cognitieve problematiek, emotionele problematiek, wetenschappelijk onderzoek (fundamenteel en/of klinisch) en, daar waar van toepassing, endocrinologie, behandeling/therapie, etc.. Een neuropsycholoog werkt nu eenmaal meestal in een multidisciplinair team en heeft als zodanig een brede functie. Het incorporeren van informatie omtrent het neurale substraat van stoornissen in normaal cognitief functioneren verbindt deze benadering aan de fundamentele neurowetenschappen. Onderwerpen die aan bod zullen komen zijn onder andere PTSS, psychopathie, eetstoornissen, hallucinaties, dissociatieve identiteitsstoornis, Korsakoff en normale en pathologische veroudering (bijv. dementie).
Na afronden van deze cursus heeft de student inzicht verkregen in:

column5: de cognitief-neuropsychologische benadering voor het beschrijven en onderzoeken van psychopathologie
de cognitieve, emotionele en neurobiologische mechanismen die kunnen leiden tot psychopathologie

column4: Het schriftelijk tentamen behorend bij deze cursus zal studenten door middel van open vragen toetsen op hun kennis betreffende cognitief-neuropsychologische aspecten van de psychiatrische stoornissen die aan bod zijn gekomen in de cursus. Studenten zullen getoetst worden op zowel kennis met betrekking tot onderzoeksmethodiek als inzicht in welke cognitief-neuropsychologische aspecten centraal staan binnen een specifieke psychiatrische stoornis, en hoe deze bij kunnen dragen aan de ontwikkeling, het verloop, de instandhouding en/of behandeling van de stoornis.

column3: De schriftelijke opdracht behorend bij deze cursus zal studenten vragen om op beknopte wijze hun kennis over een in de cursus aan bod gekomen psychiatrische/(neuro)psychologische stoornis om te zetten in een onderzoeksvoorstel waarin zij laten zien dat ze op basis van bestaande literatuur vanuit een nieuwe invalshoek een bepaalde stoornis kunnen benaderen.</body>

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

<body>Het doel van deze cursus is om 2e of 3e jaars Ba studenten vertrouwd te maken met de voor GW'ers relevante principes van het menselijk denken, voelen en handelen zoals deze worden onderzocht in de cognitieve neurowetenschap (en gerelateerde delen van de psychologie). In deze cursus: (a) raak je bekend met recente inzichten in de architectuur en de functies van het brein, en het achterliggende evolutie-biologische perspectief op die architectuur; (b) raak je vertrouwd met de bijbehorende onderzoekscultuur, inclusief de diverse gangbare onderzoeksmethoden en rapportage-genres, en de kracht en de beperkingen van dit alles; en (c) doe je vaardigheden op om vanuit eigen disciplinaire vraagstellingen de primaire en secundaire onderzoeksliteratuur in bovengenoemde disciplines te kunnen bevragen, alsmede om een dialoog met onderzoekers te kunnen aangaan.</body>

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

Muziek, literatuur, taal, beeldende kunst, film, dans, theater, televisie, internet, en games -- al deze zaken zijn door en voor mensen gemaakt, en ze dragen dus op een of andere manier altijd de signatuur van het menselijk brein. Maar hoe wérkt dat brein nou eigenlijk? In deze eerste cursus van de minor “Brains & Bodies: Cognitie en emotie in de Geesteswetenschappen” introduceren we je in het jonge vakgebied van de cognitieve neurowetenschap, en krijg je een breed maar tevens op je GW-achtergrond toegesneden inzicht in de vele vermogens van het menselijk brein. We bekijken allereerst hoe het brein qua structuur in elkaar zit, en we gaan uitvoerig in op de vele onderzoeksmethoden waarmee we de werking ervan kunnen onderzoeken (zoals EEG, MRI, TMS, lesie-onderzoek, eye tracking, en gedragstaken). Vervolgens verdiepen we ons in wat dat brein eigenlijk allemaal voor ons doet, met een focus op visuele waarneming, aandacht en bewustzijn, geheugen en plasticiteit, emoties, taal, en sociale functies. Je raakt bekend met enkele belangrijke algemene principes van het brein, zoals de grote rol van onbewuste, automatische processen (‘fast thinking’), de beperkte maar speciale bijdrage van bewuste, gecontroleerde processen (‘slow thinking’), het feit dat ons brein liever nuttige dan ‘objectieve’ representaties van de werkelijkheid opbouwt, en de evolutionaire achtergrond van dit alles. Tot slot bekijken we de soorten literatuur in dit vakgebied, en de popularisering van hersenonderzoek. Naast delen van het boek lees je ook diverse methode-illustrerende onderzoeksartikelen, zodat je vertrouwd raakt met de schrijf- en denkstijl van cognitieve neurowetenschappers, en die ook wat beter op waarde kan schatten. Al met al zal je je na deze cursus als GW’er (of andere 'dummie') veel krachtiger kunnen verhouden tot het hersenonderzoek, en op die manier ook effectiever kunnen bijdragen aan interdisciplinaire dialogen.

Let op: De cursus is GW-compatibel in de zin dat er geen voorkennis vereist is (ook geen bèta-profiel), en dat we vooral díe aspecten van de cognitieve neurowetenschap uitlichten die voor GW’ers interessant zouden kunnen zijn. Het is echter nog steeds een generieke inleiding tot het brein -- de relatie met specifieke GW-domeinen (zoals narrativiteit, performatieve kunsten, communicatie en moraliteit) wordt vooral in latere minorcursussen uitgediept.
In deze cursus is Luistertaal mogelijk, d.w.z. opdrachten e.d. mogen desgewenst ook in het Engels gemaakt worden.</body>

column3: This subject examines how mental processes are produced by human brain, specifically addressing such topics as attention, memory, executive functions, emotion, control of human locomotion and their interrelationships.
